title: Hancock v. Mid-South Management
description: In this "trip and fall" case, Hancock appeals arguing the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to the defendant.
text:
Hancock v. Mid-South Management


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Betty J. Hancock, Appellant,
v.
Mid-South Management, Co., Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Newberry County
Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4120
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 12, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Samuel M. Price, Jr., of Newberry, for Appellant.
Elizabeth M. Damzell, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.:Â  Betty Jo Hancock brought this negligence action against Mid-South Management Co., Inc. for injuries she received while walking across a parking lot owned by Mid-South.Â  Hancock appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Mid-South.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â  
FACTS
On November 5, 2001, Hancock and her daughter-in-law, Susan Hancock (Daughter), drove to the offices of The Newberry Observer, a local news agency, to pick up a newspaper.Â  After Daughter parked in the Observerâ€™s parking lot, Hancock walked toward the Observerâ€™s office building and tripped.Â  As a result of her fall, Hancock allegedly suffered physical, emotional, and financial injuries.Â  In April 2004, Hancock brought suit against Mid-South, the owner of the Observer, alleging Mid-South was negligent in maintaining the parking lot of the Observer.Â  Â Â 

 Mid-South filed a Motion for Summary Judgment, which was heard on May 5, 2005.Â  At the hearing, the parties submitted deposition testimony from Hancock and Daughter, and photographs of the parking lot in support of their respective positions.Â  Hancockâ€™s deposition testimony provides she tripped on something that was raised.Â  Hancock testified she tripped on something that â€œfelt like a rock or something to that affect,â€ and that â€œ[i]t was the broken asphalt that I tripped on.â€Â  However, Hancock also testified she could not remember exactly where she fell.Â  
Daughter, using a photograph of the Observerâ€™s parking lot, testified Hancock fell â€œ[r]ight there where things changedâ€ from asphalt to cement.Â  The photographs presented show the Observerâ€™s parking lot and an abutting cement walkway.Â  The photographs show a change in elevation at the point the asphalt meets the walkway.Â  The photographs also show that, several feet away from the walkway, portions of the Observerâ€™s parking lot are littered with rocks or broken asphalt and cracks.Â  
Also in evidence was an affidavit of Ernestine B. LeCoate, a former employee of the Newberry Publishing Company, the publisher of the Observer.Â  LeCoateâ€™s affidavit provides â€œit was a well known fact to all employees, including deponent, that the parking lot was in a deteriorated condition with potholes . . .â€ and management was aware of the parking lotâ€™s condition.Â  
At the hearing, Mid-South argued summary judgment was required because the only evidence presented establishes Hancock tripped on a change in elevation, where the pavement changes into cement.Â  Hancock argued the evidence indicates Hancockâ€™s injuries were caused by broken asphalt.Â  
The circuit court granted Mid-Southâ€™s summary judgment motion.Â  Hancock filed a Motion for Reconsideration, which was denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP. Â Nexsen v. Haddock, 353 S.C. 74, 77, 576 S.E.2d 183, 185 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Summary judgment is proper when it is clear that there is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Â Id.Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, â€œthe evidence and inferences that can be drawn therefrom should be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.â€
Tremont Constr. Co., Inc. v. Dunlap, 310 S.C. 180, 181, 425 S.E.2d 792, 793 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œIf more than one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence, the case must be submitted to the jury. However, if the evidence is susceptible of only one reasonable inference, the question is no longer one for the jury but one of law for the Court.â€Â 
Ward v. Zelinski, 260 S.C. 229, 232, 195 S.E.2d 385, 387 (1973).Â  Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Hancock contends the trial court erred in granting Mid-Southâ€™s summary judgment motion because the evidence presented demonstrates Mid-South should be liable for Hancockâ€™s injuries.Â  Specifically, Hancock argues the trial court erred in finding the Observerâ€™s parking lot did not constitute a defective or dangerous condition and Hancockâ€™s fall was not caused by an elevation change.Â  We disagree.[1]  
â€œA merchant is not an insurer of the safety of his customers but rather owes them the duty to exercise ordinary care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition.â€Â  Denton v. Winn-Dixie Greenville, Inc., 312 S.C. 119, 120, 439 S.E.2d 292, 293 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  â€˜â€œThe landowner has a duty to warn an invitee only of latent or hidden dangers of which the landowner has knowledge or should have knowledge.â€â€™Â  Larimore v. Carolina Power & Light, 340 S.C. 438, 445, 531 S.E.2d 535, 538 (Ct. App. 2000) (quoting Callander v. Charleston Doughnut Corp., 305 S.C. 123, 406 S.E.2d 361 (1991)).Â  â€œTo recover damages for injuries caused by a dangerous or defective condition on a storekeeperâ€™s premises, the plaintiff must show either (1) that the injury was caused by a specific act of the defendant which created the dangerous condition; or (2) that the defendant had actual or constructive knowledge of the dangerous condition and failed to remedy it.â€Â  Wintersteen v. Food Lion, Inc., 344 S.C. 32, 35, 542 S.E.2d 728, 729 (2001).
â€œThe mere fact that there is a difference between the levels in the different parts of the premises does not, in itself, indicate negligence unless, owing to the character, location and surrounding condition of the change of level, a reasonably careful person would not be likely to expect or see it.â€Â  Bruno v. Pendleton Realty Co., 240 S.C. 46, 51, 124 S.E.2d 580, 582 (1962).Â  Similarly, â€˜â€œ[a] step-up or step-down in a parking lot does not, in and of itself, constitute negligence.â€â€™Â  Denton, 312 S.C. at 121, 439 S.E.2d at 294 (quoting Bruno v. Pendleton Realty Co., 240 S.C. 46, 51, 124 S.E.2d 580, 582 (1962)).Â  
In Denton, this court analyzed whether a grocery store was negligent in failing to warn a customer about a cart corral in the storeâ€™s parking lot.Â  In finding the trial court should have entered judgment notwithstanding the verdict for the grocery store, the court held: 

The corral was not materially different from speed bumps, curbing, or concrete
dividers at the head of parking spaces--all of which are commonly found in or along public streets and places to park. Accidents may happen around these structures as they do on steps, escalators, and other raised structures. This does not mean they are unreasonably dangerous or that a person exercising due care would not have them on the premises. They are, in fact, common structures that a person taking reasonable care for his own safety would likely expect and see while on the premises.

312 S.C. at 121, 439 S.E.2d at 294.Â  Thus, the key question in cases involving the determination of whether a raise in elevation in or around a parking lot may be considered a dangerous or defective condition is whether the change in elevation is something â€œa person taking reasonable care for [his or her] own safety would likely expect and see while on the premises.â€Â  Id.Â  
In this case, the only testimony presented indicates Hancock fell at the point where the pavement and the cement meet.Â  Daughter testified to that effect, and Hancock could not recall the location of her fall.Â  The photographs of the Observerâ€™s parking lot clearly show a change in elevation at the point the pavement and cement meet.Â  In addition, the record provides the change in elevation was clearly visible at the time of Hancockâ€™s fall; Hancockâ€™s deposition testimony provides no debris obstructed her view of the change in elevation.Â  Based on the facts of this case, we find a person taking reasonable care should anticipate a possible change in elevation where asphalt meets an adjacent walkway.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial court did not err in finding Hancock failed to demonstrate a dangerous or defective condition caused her fall because the evidence demonstrates Hancock fell on a clear change in elevation that a person taking reasonable care would expect to see.Â  
Moreover, even if the change in elevation amounts to a dangerous or defective condition, Hancock still failed to prove Mid-South could be liable because the elevation change is an open and obvious condition.Â  â€œA landowner generally does not owe a duty to warn others of open and obvious conditions on the property.â€Â  Larimore, 340 S.C. at 445, 531 S.E.2d at 539.Â  However, a landowner may still be liable for injuries suffered from an open and obvious defect if the landowner should have anticipated the harm.Â  Callander v. Charleston Doughnut Corp., 305 S.C. 123, 125-26, 406 S.E.2d 361, 362-63 (1991).Â  A landowner may expect harm to the visitor from known or obvious dangers when the owner has reason to expect the inviteeâ€™s attention may be distracted.Â  See Larimore, 340 S.C. at 446 n.15, 531 S.E.2d at 539 n.15 (citing Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 343A (1965)).Â  We find the elevation where the asphalt meets the walkway is an open and obvious condition, and therefore, Mid-South had no duty to warn visitors of the elevation.Â  We also find Mid-South had no reason to anticipate harm to Hancock in this case because the record provides Hancock was not distracted at the time of her fall.Â  
Based on the above, we find the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment to Mid-South.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED. [2]
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We note Hancock separately addresses these issues in her brief; however, because we find the issues interrelated, we discuss them accordingly.Â  
[2] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Lockamy
description: Following a conviction for murder in the death of his brother, Dana Lockamy appeals arguing the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the law of self-defense.
text:
State v. Lockamy


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Dana Lockamy, Appellant.
      
    
  


 
Appeal From Marlboro County
Â Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4121
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 12, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Jay E. Hodge, Jr., of Cheraw, for Respondent.
      
    
  

WILLIAMS, J.: A Marlboro County jury convicted Dana Lockamy of murder in the death of his brother, James E. Lockamy, and the trial court sentenced him to thirty years in prison.Â  On appeal, Lockamy argues the trial court erred in failing to instruct the jury on the law of self-defense given the events surrounding the shooting.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The Lockamys own a thirty-acre parcel of land in Marlboro County.Â  Both Dana and his brother, James, lived on this property.Â  Dana resided in a home with his father, Andrew Lockamy, and James lived in another home located approximately a quarter of a mile away.Â  Andrew Lockamy owns and operates a trucking business that utilizes tractor-trailer trucks to haul commodities from state to state.Â  The brothers both worked for their father driving the trucks.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On May 25, 2002, Dana and his father returned home after hauling a load of produce to Florida.Â  Shortly after their arrival, James called and asked Dana if he could borrow a set of hand tools to work on a lawnmower.Â Â Â  Dana said that he could and drove the short distance to his brotherâ€™s house with the tool set.[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â 
When Dana arrived at his brotherâ€™s house he found James standing outside near a workbench working on the lawnmower.Â  James walked over to the truck and Dana handed him the tool set through the passenger side window.Â  As the tool set was handed over, Dana asked that James be careful and not lose any of the tools.Â  At this point, according to Dana, James became enraged, began cursing at him, and threatened to â€œbeat [his] brains out and leave [him] lying in a pool of blood.â€Â  
After throwing the tool set back into the truck, James strode around to the driverâ€™s side window and began beating Dana in the head with a stick.Â  Dana grabbed the stick and threw it out of the passenger window, after which James continued to hit Dana with his fists.Â  In an attempt to stop the beating, Dana began to drive off, but James grabbed Danaâ€™s arm and continued to strike him.Â  Unable to drive away, Dana stopped the truck and attempted to get out of the vehicle.Â  As he attempted to exit, James slammed the car door on him pinning Dana between the door and the body of the truck.Â  
Having freed himself from the car door, Dana leaned against the bed of the truck to recover.Â  James then walked a short distance away and retrieved a large iron pipe which he used to beat Dana in the arms, hips, and ribs.Â  Dana testified that when he retrieved the pipe, James was holding it â€œmarching back and forth like a Roman soldierâ€ and shouting â€œIâ€™ve got the power, Iâ€™ve got the power.â€[2]Â  After sustaining several blows with the pipe, Dana, being the larger of the two brothers, was able to wrest the pipe away from James.Â  Having been disarmed, James again began striking Dana in the head and body with his fists.Â  According to Dana, the repeated assaults lasted approximately ten minutes.Â  
When the attack subsided, Dana testified that James walked a short distance away and began laughing and joking about the beating he gave Dana.Â  James also stated that next time he would finish beating Danaâ€™s brains out and then go to their fatherâ€™s home and do the same to him.Â  Dana got back in the truck and drove out of Jamesâ€™ yard and down the street when he noticed in the rear-view mirror that his face was covered in blood.Â  He also noticed his sunglasses were missing and that his glass eye was not in place.Â  At that point, Dana assumed the glass eye was knocked out during the altercation, but it was learned after the incident that he took the glass eye out before he drove to Jamesâ€™ house.Â  
Having noticed his injuries, Dana drove the short distance to the house he shared with his father and retrieved a shotgun.Â  Dana testified that he thought mistakenly â€œsurely . . . he would not attack me if I had a weapon when I returned.â€Â  Dana stated that he wanted to return to his brotherâ€™s house to retrieve his glass eye, which, as noted previously, he mistakenly thought was knocked out by the assault.
When Dana arrived back at Jamesâ€™ he left the gun in the truck, got out, and noticed one of Jamesâ€™ friends handing him a packet of drugs.Â  James started to brag about beating Dana with his fists and then asked Dana if he could still borrow the tool set.Â  Dana responded that he could not borrow the tools and this again enraged James.Â  Having been denied the use of his brotherâ€™s tools, James picked up a socket wrench and approached Dana with it raised above his head, poised to strike.Â  As he approached, he threatened to knock Danaâ€™s good eye out of his head.Â  
Dana backed up towards the truck, reached through the window and retrieved the gun.Â  Dana stated that his intention was to fire a shot into the ground.Â  Meanwhile James continued to threaten Dana and his father.Â  Even after seeing the gun, James advanced towards Dana and attempted to strike him with the ratchet.Â  Dana got down on his knees and attempted to cover his head with one of his arms while James was standing above him with the gun sticking out between Jamesâ€™ legs.Â  
When James went to strike Dana with the wrench, Dana was able to locate and disengage the safety on the gun and pump a shell into the chamber.Â  At this point, James dropped the wrench and started to run away.Â  Dana then stood up and walked a short distance holding the gun down by his side.Â  As James ran away, Dana said â€œdonâ€™t ever beat me in my head and face like that again, and donâ€™t ever come to our fatherâ€™s home and harm him in any way or there will be no warning shot fired the next time.â€Â  
James ran around a large tree and across a small garden[3] before Dana, still holding the gun at his side, fired one shot through the tree in the direction James was running.Â  Dana testified that at the time he fired the shot, he could not see James.Â  After approximately one minute, James walked back into view towards Dana.Â  Dana stated that he noticed a small amount of blood on Jamesâ€™ arm, but otherwise did not think James was seriously injured.Â  Dana got back in his truck, drove home to his fatherâ€™s house, and began to wash blood off his face.Â  In fact, he was so occupied when the police arrived to arrest him a short time later.
When paramedics arrived at the scene of the shooting, they found James deceased, lying in a field beside his home.Â  The coroner determined he died from a single gunshot wound to the back.Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Dana argues that given the particular facts surrounding the incident, the trial court erred in refusing to charge the jury on the law of self-defense.
â€œâ€˜An appellate court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision regarding jury instructions unless the trial court abused its discretion.â€™â€Â  State v. Williams, 367 S.C. 192, 195, 624 S.E.2d 443, 445 (Ct. App. 2005) (quoting Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000)).Â  Furthermore, â€œthe trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury instruction must be both erroneous and prejudicial to warrant reversal.â€Â  State v. Light, 363 S.C. 325, 330, 610 S.E.2d 504, 506 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  However, if there is any evidence to support the requested charge, the trial court should grant the request.Â  Williams, at 195, 624 S.E.2d at 445.
Dana argued at trial that he shot his brother in self-defense.Â  In South Carolina, four elements must exist for a defendant to be entitled to a self-defense charge: 

(1) the defendant must be without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) the defendant must have been in actual imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury, or he must have actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) if his defense is based upon his belief of imminent danger, defendant must show that a reasonably prudent person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the belief that he was actually in imminent danger and that the circumstances were such as would warrant a person of ordinary prudence, firmness, and courage to strike the fatal blow in order to save himself from serious bodily harm or the loss of his life; and (4) the defendant had no other probable means of avoiding the danger. 

State v. Day, 341 S.C. 410, 416, 535 S.E.2d 431, 434 (2002) (citing State v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 520 S.E.2d 319 (1999)).Â  
Before making its ruling in the current case, the trial court carefully and thoughtfully considered the propriety of charging the jury on self-defense.Â  The court was particularly concerned about the fourth element of the defense â€“ that Dana had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.Â  As the court noted, if James had been shot while he was still standing over Dana attempting to strike him, it would be clear that Dana would be entitled to the instruction.Â  However, Dana was no longer in danger when he fired the shot.Â  His own testimony belies his position.Â  Dana stated that James ran and that he was fifty feet away when the fatal shot was fired.Â  
Accordingly, we agree with the trial court that the fourth element of self-defense was not proven and therefore, find the trial court did not err by refusing the instruction.
AFFIRMED. [4]
KITTREDGE and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Although accounts of what happened next vary according to the different witnesses, for purposes of this opinion, we construe the facts as related by Danaâ€™s trial testimony.Â Â Â  
[2] Dana testified that he believed James was in a â€œdrug-induced rageâ€ and that his peculiar behavior resulted from being under the influence of some type of drug.Â  In fact, he testified that at one point during the beating he asked James what he â€œgot ahold ofâ€ and James responded that he got some really good drugs from North Carolina.Â  
[3] Â Dana stated that he believed James was approximately 50 feet away when the shot was fired.Â  
[4] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Grant v. Mount Vernon Mills
description: This is an appeal from the granting of Mount Vernon Mills' motion for summary judgment as to Grant's claims for breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by fraudulent act, and breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing in connection with the termination of Grant's employment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Cynthia K. Grant, Appellant,
v.
Mount Vernon Mills, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4122
Heard May 11, 2006 â€“ Filed June 12, 2006

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Candy Kern-Fuller, of Piedmont, for Appellant.
Thomas A. Bright, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  This is a breach of contract action based on an employee handbook.Â  The employee, Cynthia K. Grant, appeals from the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Mount Vernon Mills, Inc.Â  We affirm and hold that the termination provisions in the employee handbook did not apply to Grant (as a salaried employee), and that in any event, the termination policy provisions of the handbook are permissive in nature and did not alter the at-will relationship. 
I.
We apply the same standard as the circuit court when reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP;Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  To determine whether any material fact exists, the evidence and all reasonable inferences must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  South Carolina Prop. & Cas. Guar. Assâ€™n v. Yensen, 345 S.C. 512, 518, 548 S.E.2d 880, 883 (Ct. App. 2001).  Â Â 
Once the party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing the absence of a genuine issue as to any material fact, the nonmoving party may not simply rest on the mere allegations contained in the pleadings.Â  Peterson v. W. Am. Ins. Co., 336 S.C. 89, 94, 518 S.E.2d 608, 610 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œRather, the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine issue for trial.â€Â  Id.Â  â€œThe purpose of summary judgment is to expedite disposition of cases which do not require the services of a fact finder.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).
 II. 
In 1996, Grant began her salaried employment with Mount Vernon as a Pension Benefits Manager.Â  Grantâ€™s duties included processing monthly pensions payroll, conducting interviews with plan participants, and reviewing termination packages for terminated employees.Â  Grant received a copy of the employee handbook.Â Â  Â Â Â 
The employee handbook contains numerous policies, including Employment Policy and Practice, Union Policy, Relocation Policy, Jury Duty, Terminations, Employment of Family Relatives, and so forth.Â  Each policy in the manual hasâ€”at the top of the pageâ€”the term â€œCOVERAGE.â€Â  The policies apply to a variety of employee classifications.Â  Some policies apply to â€œALL EMPLOYEESâ€; some policies apply to â€œSALARIED EMPLOYEESâ€; some apply to â€œSALARIED EMPLOYEES â€“ EXEMPT AND NONEXEMPTâ€; some apply to â€œHOURLY EMPLOYEESâ€; some apply to â€œHOURLY NONEXEMPT EMPLOYEESâ€; and one policy applies to â€œFIRST LINE SUPERVISORS.â€ Â As noted, Grant was a salaried employee.
At issue here is the handbookâ€™s termination policy that provides â€œCOVERAGEâ€ for â€œHOURLY NONEXEMPT EMPLOYEESâ€ and states in relevant part:

I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Policy
It is the policy of the Company to attempt to be fair and just in all dealings with employees.Â  For purposes of this policy, a termination is the result of any action initiated by the employee or the Company whereby the service record of the employee is broken.
. . . .
B. DisciplineÂ  
1.Â  Notice of WarningsÂ  
a) Warnings are normally given as a result of an employeeâ€™s unsatisfactory conduct or performance.Â  The purpose of the warning is to serve notice to the employee that a continuation of the practice may result in discharge and to advise the employee that a change in conduct or performance must be made.Â  
b) Warnings should be administered by the employeeâ€™s immediate supervisor and should be straight forward and sincere.Â  The supervisor should assume the responsibility and attitude of being helpful. 
. . . .
2.     Discharge  
a)Â  The three warnings and final improper conduct or performance will result in discharge if all four take place in a twelve consecutive month period.
. . . .
d)Â  Immediate dischargeÂ  
. . . .
4) Offenses - It is not the Companyâ€™s intent to list in detail everything that an employee should or should not do under all circumstances.Â  The following offenses are only examples of the types of conduct which could result in immediate discharge:
. . . .
d) Creating discord or lack of harmony; . . . .

(emphasis added). 
On September 13, 2000, Grant met with three of her supervisors, Kent Harris, Ned Cochrane, and Gary Williams.Â  Grant was terminated, effective immediately.Â  The supervisors told Grant the reasons for her termination, and those reasons relate to their perception of Grantâ€™s poor work performance and her creating discord and lack of harmony in the workplace.Â  Harris informed Grant she was terminated for her performance problems and lack of effort to work in a team environment within the corporate setting.Â  Further, he stated she consistently displayed a poor attitude as evidenced by various emails she sent.Â  In one of those emails Grant complained about being asked to perform employee interviews.Â  She concluded by asking, â€œSo do we just get the crappy work dumped on us?â€Â  In addition to Grantâ€™s supervisorsâ€™ belief of her negative attitude towards employees and her work, Harris stated Grant performed her job poorly.Â  Â Â Â Â Â 
Grant filed suit in the circuit court alleging race and sex discrimination in violation of Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, as well as state claims for breach of contract, breach of contract accompanied by fraudulent act, and breach of the covenant of good faith and fair dealing.Â  
Mount Vernon removed the action to federal district court and filed a motion for summary judgment on all claims.Â  The federal district court granted Mount Vernon summary judgment as to the federal claims and remanded the various contract claims to state court.Â  
On remand to state court, Mount Vernon moved for summary judgment.Â  Mount Vernon alleged the various contract claims were premised on the existence of an employment contract, and no contract existed as a matter of law because Grant was employed at-will.Â  Mount Vernon maintained the employee handbook policy plainly stated the termination policy only applied to hourly nonexempt employees, and Grant was a salaried employee.Â  Mount Vernon contended that because the termination policy did not apply to Grant, her at-will status was not altered.Â Â  Accordingly, Mount Vernon claimed Grantâ€™s breach of contract claims failed as a matter of law.Â  
Grant countered that during her employment she reviewed various salaried employee files that contained written warnings prior to termination.Â  Grant also submitted various affidavits from salaried employees who stated they received written warnings prior to termination.Â  Further, Grant submitted affidavits from two managers who stated they gave written warnings to salaried employees prior to termination.Â  Grantâ€™s position was and remains that if other salaried employees received warnings, so should she.
Grant additionally relied on Mount Vernonâ€™s failure to insert a conspicuous disclaimer in the handbook to express its desire to maintain the at-will employment relationship.[1]Â  Therefore, Grant contended that a question of fact existed as to whether the handbook created a binding contract, meaning Grant could only be fired for cause.Â  
The circuit court granted Mount Vernon summary judgment.Â  The circuit court reasoned the termination policy stated that coverage was for hourly nonexempt employees and because Grant was a salaried employee no ambiguity existed as to the fact she fell outside the scope of the policy.Â  Therefore, the circuit court found the employee handbook did not create a contract of employment that modified Grantâ€™s at-will status.Â  Moreover, the circuit court rejected Grantâ€™s reliance on Mount Vernonâ€™s decision to give warnings to other at-will employees and not her.Â  This appeal followed.
III.
Grant maintains the circuit court erred in concluding Mount Vernonâ€™s employee handbook, as a matter of law, did not alter Grantâ€™s status as an at-will employee.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina has long recognized the doctrine of employment at-will.Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 471, 611 S.E.2d 905, 910-11 (2005) (Conner II); Shealy v. Fowler, 182 S.C. 81, 87, 188 S.E. 499, 502 (1936) (â€œ[a] contract for permanent employment, so long as it is satisfactorily performed, which is not supported by any consideration other than the obligation of service to be performed on the one hand and wages to be paid on the other, is terminable at the pleasure of either party.â€).Â  This doctrine allows either party to terminate the employment â€œfor any reason or no reasonâ€ without being subject to a claim for breach of contract, subject to narrow exceptions and prohibitions against illegal discrimination which are not present here.Â  Horton v. Darby Elec. Co., Inc., 360 S.C. 58, 67, 599 S.E.2d 456, 460 (2004); see also Conner II, 363 S.C. at 471, 611 S.E.2d at 910.Â  The at-will employment doctrine is essentially an economic incentive that provides critically needed flexibility in the marketplace.Â  Prescott v. Farmers Tel. Co-op., Inc., 335 S.C. 330, 334-35, 516 S.E.2d 923, 925 (1999).
When the at-will status of an employee is altered by the terms of an employee handbook, however, a contract may arise allowing for a cause of action for wrongful discharge.Â  Small v. Springs Indus., Inc., 292 S.C. 481, 484, 357 S.E.2d 452, 454 (1987).Â Â  
When the evidence conflicts or is capable of more than one inference, the issue of whether an employee handbook constitutes a contract should be submitted to the jury; however, â€œâ€˜a court should intervene to resolve the handbook issue as a matter of law . . . if the handbook statements and the disclaimer, taken together, establish beyond any doubt tha[t] an enforceable promise either does or does not exist.â€™â€Â  Hessenthaler v. Tri-County Sister Help, Inc., 365 S.C. 101, 108, 616 S.E.2d 694, 697 (2005) (quoting Stephen F. Befort, Employee Handbooks and the Legal Effect of Disclaimers, 13 Indus. Rel. L.J. 326, 375-76 (1991-92)).Â  
The typical handbook employment case may be resolved by making three determinations.Â  A handbook forms an employment contract when: (1) the handbook provision(s) and procedure(s) in question apply to the employee, (2) the handbook sets out procedures binding on the employer, and (3) the handbook does not contain a conspicuous and appropriate disclaimer.Â  See Conner II, 363 S.C. at 472, 611 S.E.2d at 911; see also Williams v. Riedman, 339 S.C. 251, 259-60, 529 S.E.2d 28, 32 (Ct. App. 2000) (citing Miller v. Schmid Labs., Inc., 307 S.C. 140, 414 S.E.2d 126 (1992)).Â  
In determining whether the handbook sets out procedures that bind an employer, we must first determineâ€”because of the procedural posture of this caseâ€”whether the employee is covered by the policy provision in question.Â  If the employee is not covered, then the handbook would not form the basis of an employment contract.Â  
Assuming an employee is covered by the relevant provision in the handbook, we next determine whether the handbook sets out binding procedures on the employer.Â  In this regard, in the absence of a conspicuous and appropriate disclaimer, if the language in the handbook sets out mandatory, progressive discipline procedures, those procedures alter the at-will employment relationship.Â  When an employer discharges a covered employee without adhering to the mandatory procedures, the employee may maintain an action for wrongful discharge against the employer. See Hessenthaler, 365 S.C. at 108-09, 616 S.E.2d at 697-98 (citing Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 348 S.C. 454, 463-64, 560 S.E.2d 606, 610-11 (2002) (Conner I)).
Mandatory discipline procedures â€œtypically provide that an employee may be fired only after certain steps are taken.Â  When definite and mandatory, these procedures impose a limitation on the employerâ€™s right to terminate an employee at any time, for any reason.â€ Â Hessenthaler, 365 S.C. at 109, 616 S.E.2d at 698.Â  Permissive language in an employee handbook, on the other hand, does not alter an employeeâ€™s at-will status.Â  See Horton 360 S.C. at 67-68, 599 S.E.2d at 461 (affirming summary judgment for employer when handbook provided discipline procedures that contained permissive language).Â  
A.Â Â Â Â Â  Mount Vernonâ€™s employee handbook termination policy does not apply to Grant, a salaried employee.
Grant contends a jury question exists as to whether the employee handbookâ€™s termination policy applies to her.Â  We disagree. 
The employee handbookâ€™s termination policy unambiguously states that it applies to hourly nonexempt employees.Â  Grant was a salaried, not an hourly, employee.Â  According to Grant, she was a â€œsalaried non-exempt employee.â€ Â App. Br. at 10.Â  Grant focuses exclusively on the exempt versus nonexempt issue.[2]Â Â  We need not reach the issue of whether Grant was exempt or nonexempt, for she was indisputably not an hourly employee.Â  Because Grant was not an hourly nonexempt employee, the termination policy in the handbook did not apply to her. 
Grant additionally argues that because the termination provision provides that the company policy is to be â€œfair and just in all dealings with employees,â€ the termination provision applies to all employees, including salaried and hourly employees.Â  The phrase â€œemployeesâ€ in the body of the provision may not be properly read to broaden the coverage beyond that clearly set forth in the heading of the policy.Â  This general policy statementâ€”to be â€œfair and justâ€â€”does not somehow expand the class of Mount Vernon employees to whom this provision applies. This provision, by unmistakable language, is limited to hourly nonexempt employees.Â Â  
Beyond this, the law does not sanction the leap advocated by Grant.Â  For a general policy statement to be enforceable as a contract, the statement â€œmust be definitive in nature, promising specific treatment in specific situations.â€Â  Hessenthaler, 365 S.C. at 110, 616 S.E.2d at 698 (finding that because nondiscrimination provision was not specific and did not make any promises regarding disciplinary procedure or termination decisions, the handbook did not contain promises enforceable as a contract).Â  The policy statement of Mount Vernon to be â€œfair and justâ€ does not create an expectation that employment is guaranteed or that a particular process must be complied with before an employee is terminated.Â  Consequently, the policy statement does not create a contract or otherwise alter Grantâ€™s at-will status.
Grant seeks to avoid the coverage limitation in the termination policy by claiming that her termination is governed by the â€œATTENDANCEâ€ policy, which applies to â€œALL EMPLOYEES.â€Â  This argument finds insufficient traction in the record.Â  Grant recalled in her deposition testimony that the reason given at the September 13, 2000, meeting for her termination was that she was â€œnot a team player.â€Â  The balance of the record is consistent with Grantâ€™s recollection of the September 13 meeting in which she was terminated for her poor attitude and â€œnot working as part of a team.â€Â  Grant points to the September 13 memorandum of Gary Williams which contains, among many other things, a reference to Grantâ€™s propensity for arriving late for work and leaving early as â€œone contributing factor to the overall problem â€“ an example of how her attitude has affected her performance [at Mount Vernon].â€Â Â  
We agree with the assessment of the circuit court that the language of the attendance policy would create an issue of fact if the evidence could reasonably support the conclusion that Grant was terminated for attendance reasons.Â  The evidence (in a light most favorable to Grant) establishes, however, that Grantâ€™s alleged attendance related issues were only an adjunct in the decision to terminate her.Â  As former Chief Justice Littlejohn observed, we are not â€œrequired to single out some one morsel of evidence and attach to it great significance when patently the evidence is introduced solely in a vain attempt to create an issue of fact that is not genuine.â€Â  Main v. Corley, 281 S.C. 525, 527, 316 S.E.2d 406, 407 (1984). 
B.Â Â Â Â Â  An employee handbook couched in permissive language does not alter the at-will employment relationship.
Although Grant may not avail herself of the termination policy due to her status as a salaried employee, we address Grantâ€™s contention that a handbook (whether couched in mandatory or permissive language) always alters the at-will relationship of the employer and employee absent a conspicuous disclaimer to the contrary.  In support of her argument, Grant cites to the supreme courtâ€™s statement in Conner I â€œthat if an employer wishes to issue written policies, but intends to continue at-will employment [and not be bound by the polices], the employer must insert a conspicuous disclaimer into the handbook.â€  Conner I, 348 S.C. at 463, 560 S.E.2d at 611.
Grant, however, overlooks that the analysis in Conner I is based upon mandatory language that binds the employer.  See Connor I, 348 S.C. at 464, 560 S.E.2d at 611.Â  The supreme court observed in Conner I that â€œ[i]t is patently unjust to allow an employer to couch a handbook, bulletin, or other similar material in mandatory terms and then allow him to ignore these very policies.â€Â  Conner I, 348 S.C. at 463, 560 S.E.2d at 610 (quoting Small v. Springs Indus., Inc., 292 S.C. at 485, 357 S.E.2d at 455).
In the present case, because nothing in the employee handbook outlined progressive disciplinary procedures in mandatory terms, the presumption that the employment was at-will was not rebutted and no disclaimer was needed.Â  Accordingly, we hold the handbook did not contain promises enforceable in contract.Â  
Even assuming Grant may avail herself of Mount Vernonâ€™s termination policy, her contract claims must nevertheless fail.Â  The permissive nature of the termination policy compels this result.Â  Nothing in the employee handbook required Mount Vernon to give warnings to an employee before termination.Â  The handbook provides: â€œWarnings are normally given as a result of an employeeâ€™s unsatisfactory conduct or performance.â€ (emphasis added).Â  Moreover, the handbook states that if a warning is given then â€œ[w]arnings should be administered by the employeeâ€™s immediate supervisor and should be straight forward and sincere.â€Â  Therefore, a plain reading of the handbook shows that a supervisor may give a warning, but is not required to do so.Â  If a warning is given, then the handbook provides procedures on how the warning should be administered.[3]
C.Â Â Â Â Â  Grantâ€™s status as an at-will employee is not altered by MountÂ Â Â Â  Vernonâ€™s election to give a warning to other salaried employees.
Grantâ€™s final argument is premised on the notion that an employer may not treat at-will employees differently.Â  Grant points to evidence of other salaried employees receiving warnings.Â  If other presumably at-will employees received warnings instead of dismissal, then Grant contends she is legally entitled to the same consideration.Â  Although the law prohibits illegal discrimination, Grant makes no such claim to us.Â  The record provides little in terms of the at-will salaried employees who were given warnings.Â  We do not know the tenure of these employees, Mount Vernonâ€™s perception of the value of these employees, and the nature of the alleged misconduct of these employees.Â  We decline to speculate that the circumstances of these examples of salaried employees receiving warnings mirror Grantâ€™s situation.
We agree with the circuit court that Grantâ€™s reference to other salaried employees receiving warnings does not create a question of fact.Â  Absent a claim of illegal discrimination, an employeeâ€™s status as an at-will employee is not altered by an employerâ€™s decision to give a warning to other at-will employees.
The rule could not be otherwise without wreaking havoc on the at-will employment doctrine.Â  Employers routinely give warnings to at-will employees when no warning is legally required.Â  But those at-will employees who are summarily fired and do not receive warnings may not (absent illegal discrimination) bootstrap an employerâ€™s unrelated judgment in another employeeâ€™s situation to alter the at-will relationship and create a contract of employment.Â  From the employerâ€™s perspective, that is the essence of the at-will employment relationship.
Say, for example, an employer has two at-will employees who have committed the same infraction and assume the absence of illegal discrimination.Â  Employee A has worked for employer for ten years, and employer perceives employee A as a long time valued employee.Â  Employer elects to give employee A a warning.Â  Assume employee B has worked for employer for one year and employer perceives employee B as only a marginally adequate employee.Â  Employer elects to fire employee B.Â  Does employerâ€™s decision to give employee A a warning alter employee Bâ€™s at-will status, entitling employee B to a warning?Â  The answer is â€œno.â€Â  The result would be the same if we reversed the hypothetical.Â  Though illogical, the at-will employment doctrine would allow the employer to fire employee A and merely warn employee B.Â  Absent a contract of employment or other legally cognizable claim, courts have no business interfering with employersâ€™ decisions to warn or fire at-will employees.Â  
We additionally conclude that Mount Vernonâ€™s perception that it had cause for terminating Grant does not alter the at-will relationship.Â  Employers will almost always believe there is â€œgood causeâ€ for terminating an employee, including an at-will employee.Â  The fact that an employer claims it takes no disciplinary action without a good reason does not mean the employer can only act in the presence of a good reason.Â  This court reached a similar result in Davis v. Orangeburg-Calhoun Law Enforcement Comâ€™n, 344 S.C. 240, 542 S.E.2d 755 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Davis claimed an employment contract was created when his employer told him â€œhe could â€˜only be terminated for cause.â€™â€Â  Id. at 249, 542 S.E.2d at 760.Â  We held such a statement â€œinsufficient by itself to provide a factual issue as to alteration of Davisâ€™s at-will employment status.â€Â  Id. (citing with approval Montgomery County Hosp. Dist. v. Brown, 965 S.W.2d 501, 502 (Tex. 1998) (statements that an employee will be discharged only for â€œgood reasonâ€ or â€œgood causeâ€ do not form a binding contract â€œwhen there is no agreement on what those terms encompass. Without such agreement the employee cannot reasonably expect to limit the employerâ€™s right to terminate him.â€)).Â Â  
IV. 
We find Mount Vernonâ€™s termination policy did not apply to Grant as a salaried employee, and for the reasons discussed above, we hold that an at-will employment relationship existed between Grant and Mount Vernon.Â  We join the circuit court in concluding that Mount Vernon was entitled to summary judgment.Â Â  
AFFIRMED.
SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]  The title page of the handbook (entitled â€œEmployee Policies and Procedures On-Line Guideâ€) states that the â€œon-line policy guide is not intended to bind the Company or any employee to a specific period of employment.â€Â  This language was neither bold nor capitalized. 
[2]  The parties have not developed the status of Grant as exempt or nonexempt as significant to a resolution of this appeal.Â  From our review of the record, it appears this issue may have been relevant in the adjudication of Grantâ€™s previously dismissed federal claims.Â  For example, Grant submitted an affidavit in opposition to the summary judgment motion filed in federal court, in which Grantâ€™s expert opined that, for purposes of exemption from the overtime requirements of the Fair Labor Standards Act, Grant was â€œnot an â€˜exemptâ€™ employeeâ€ with Mount Vernon. 
[3]  This serves as an additional sustaining ground.Â  See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 419, 526 S.E.2d 716, 723 (2000) (â€œ[A] respondent . . . may raise on appeal any additional reasons the appellate court should affirm the lower courtâ€™s ruling, regardless of whether those reasons have been presented to or ruled on by the lower court.â€).

title: SCDSS v. Walter
description: In this termination of parental rights action, the issue is whether the fact that the intervention action proceeded to trial while related criminal charges were pending violated Nelson's constitutional due process or equal protection rights.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
v.
Michelle Walter, William Nelson, and Ricardo Pagan,
Defendants,
of whom William Nelson is Appellant.
In the interest of:Â  Jane Doe, 02/25/1988
A minor under the age of 18.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Alvin D. Johnson, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4125
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 14, 2006Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Fletcher N. Smith, Jr., of Greenville, for Appellant. 
Harry LaDon Phillips, Jr., of Greenville, for Respondent.
Michael Anthony Andrews, of Easley, for Guardian Ad Litem. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  The issue presented in this appeal is whether William Nelsonâ€™s due process and equal protection rights were violated by the fact that the family court intervention action proceeded to trial while related criminal charges were also pending against him.Â  We find no constitutional violation and affirm.[1]  
I.
In June of 2004, the South Carolina Department of Social Services brought a removal action against Michelle Walter, Ricardo Pagan, and William Nelson alleging that Walter and Pagan left Jane Doe,[2] a sixteen-year-old female, in the custody of Nelson, who sexually abused her and allowed her to smoke marijuana.Â  At the family court probable cause hearing, Nelson appeared with counsel and raised concerns that he might not be able to testify due to pending criminal charges.Â  The family court denied the request to hold the family intervention action in abeyance pending resolution of the criminal charges.Â  
A trial was held, and the family court found that Nelson had sexually abused Doe.Â  Nelson did not testify at the hearing.Â  Nelson appeals. 
II. 
Nelson argues on appeal that his equal protection and due process rights were violated by the family courtâ€™s failure to hold the family court action in abeyance pending resolution of the related criminal charges.Â  The essence of Nelsonâ€™s position is that the pending criminal charges (and his right to remain silent) unduly and impermissibly influenced his decision whether to testify in the family court action and, more generally, his ability to defend himself against the family court abuse allegations, amounting to a constitutional violation.Â  
Case law from other jurisdictions has uniformly rejected Nelsonâ€™s constitutional challenge.Â  United States v. Kordel, 397 U.S. 1, 11 (1970) (holding that simultaneous civil and related criminal proceedings do not constitute â€œunfairness and want of consideration of justiceâ€ requiring reversal of a criminal conviction); Peiffer v. Lebanon Sch. Dist., 848 F.2d 44, 46 (3rd Cir. 1988) (holding there was no constitutional requirement that the administrative hearing be postponed pending disposition of the criminal charges); Wimmer v. Lehman, 705 F.2d 1402, 1406-1407 (4th Cir. 1983), cert. denied, 464 U.S. 992 (1983) (same); Â Hoover v. Knight, 678 F.2d 578, 581 (5th Cir. 1982) (â€œMany cases have held that parallel criminal and civil trials or investigations do not raise questions of constitutional magnitude with respect to the privilege against self-incrimination.â€); Diebold v. Civil Serv. Commâ€™n of St. Louis County, 611 F.2d 697, 700-01 (8th Cir. 1979) (holding that the Fifth Amendment presents no obstacle to parallel criminal and administrative proceedings); Arthurs v. Stern, 560 F.2d 477, 478-80 (1st Cir. 1977), cert. denied, 434 U.S. 1034 (1978) (holding that a physician accused of writing illegal prescriptions was not entitled, by virtue of his right to be free of coerced self-incrimination, to continuance of disciplinary proceedings until the criminal charges arising out of the same conduct were resolved); Gabrilowitz v. Newman, 582 F.2d 100, 104 (1st Cir. 1978) (holding that the fact that parallel proceedings force a defendant to make a difficult choice as to whether to testify does not of itself violate the constitution); United States v. Rubinson, 543 F.2d 951, 961-62 (2nd Cir. 1976), cert. denied, 429 U.S. 850 (1976)Â  (holding that the Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination was not prejudiced by a prior administrative proceeding based on the same facts); State ex rel. Okla. Bar Assâ€™n v. Gasaway,  863 P.2d 1189, 1195-98 (Okla. 1993) (holding a continuance of lawyer disciplinary proceedings pending resolution of related criminal proceedings is not constitutionally required); Giampa v. Ill. Civil Serv. Commâ€™n, 411 N.E.2d 1110, 1116 (Ill. App. Ct. 1980) (holding there is nothing inherently repugnant to due process in requiring a party to choose between giving testimony at a disciplinary hearing and keeping silent, even though giving testimony at the hearing may damage his criminal case and keeping silent will most likely lead to loss of his employment).Â  Nelson cites no law to the contrary.
We are further mindful of the statutory mandate for an expedited resolution in family court intervention actions.Â  A removal action should be resolved in an expedited manner for the protection of an abused or neglected child.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 20-7-610 and 20-7-736 (Supp. 2005).
Nelson was present at the hearing and was represented by counsel.Â  His decision whether to testify, while admittedly a difficult one for tactical reasons, did not implicate either the state or federal constitutions.Â  Because no constitutional issue was at stake, we review under an abuse of discretion standard the family courtâ€™s denial of Nelsonâ€™s motion to delay the intervention action.Â  Â We find no abuse of discretion in the family courtâ€™s denial of Nelsonâ€™s motion.Â  
AFFIRMED. 
KITTREDGE, SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur. 

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  We use of the name Doe in light of the allegations and findings of sexual abuse.

title: Fryer v. SLED
description: Affirms the trial court's order requiring the expungement of a magistrate court conviction for petit larceny.
text:
Fryer v. SLED


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Marcus Fryer, Respondent,
v.
South Carolina Law Enforcement Division, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
J. Ernest Kinard, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4123
Submitted May 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Deputy Attorney General T. Stephen Lynch, and Assistant Attorney General Elizabeth R. McMahon, all of Columbia, for Appellant.
Marcus Fryer, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  The South Carolina Law Enforcement Division (SLED) appeals a trial courtâ€™s order expunging the record of Marcus Fryerâ€™s conviction for petit larceny.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
Fryer alleges he was arrested on February 26, 1989, arising from his attempt to purchase a bag of chips from a vending machine.Â  When the machine failed to eject the chips, Fryer shook the machine, causing the glass front to break.Â  Fryer was charged with petit larceny.Â  By arrest warrant dated March 16, 1989, Fryer was also charged with malicious injury to personal property.Â  Fryer testified both charges arose from the vending machine incident, and he was arrested only one time for the incident.Â  He pled guilty in magistrate court to both charges in a single hearing.Â  
In 1998, Fryer petitioned the court for expungement of his arrest record.Â  By order dated October 9, 1998, the court issued an order expunging the malicious injury to personal property charge.Â  SLED expunged only the record of that charge.Â  When Fryer learned only one charge had been expunged, he petitioned the court for expungement of the petit larceny charge. 
At a hearing on Fryerâ€™s petition, SLED submitted fingerprint cards dated February 26, 1989 and March 16, 1989, arguing the separate cards indicated separate arrests which, in turn, indicated separate incidents.Â  Fryer attempted to retrieve the magistrateâ€™s records and was informed the magistrate no longer had the files because, according to the magistrate, the charges had already been expunged. Â 
By order dated June 25, 2000, the court ordered the petit larceny charge expunged.Â  The order was forwarded to SLED for execution.Â  SLED wrote a letter to the judge requesting advice as SLEDâ€™s records showed Fryer was not eligible for expungement of the petit larceny charge.Â  However, SLED did not move for reconsideration or appeal the 2000 order.Â  
SLED did not expunge the petit larceny charge.Â  In April of 2002, after Fryer learned the charge had not been expunged, he again petitioned for expungement of the petit larceny charge based on the June 25, 2000 order.Â  The trial court held an evidentiary hearing on the petition.
The trial court made the factual finding that Fryer was arrested once based on the vending machine incident and both charges stemmed from that incident.Â  Fryer and his mother each testified there was only one arrest arising from a single incident.Â  SLED employee Joseph E. Means, Jr. admitted that SLED expunges multiple offenses arising from a single arrest.Â  SLED contended, however, that because the fingerprint cards were dated over a week apart, and because the warrants for the two offenses were not in numeric order, there must have been two arrests arising from two incidents.Â  
By order dated August 4, 2004, the court, interpreting Fryerâ€™s petition as a petition for a writ of mandamus, found one arrest arising from a single incident, concluded the 2000 order was valid, and granted mandamus.Â  SLED appeals.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
SLED argues the 2000 order expunging the petit larceny charge is void because it is in violation of South Carolina Code section 22-5-910.[2]Â  We disagree.
The 2000 order of expungement is not void.Â  A void judgment is one that, from its inception, is a complete nullity and is without legal effect and must be distinguished from one that is merely voidable.Â  Thomas & Howard Co. v. T.W. Graham & Co., 318 S.C. 286, 291, 457 S.E.2d 340, 343 (1995).Â  â€œThe definition of â€˜voidâ€™ . . . encompasses judgments from courts which . . . lacked subject matter jurisdiction . . . .â€Â  McDaniel v. U.S. Fid. & Guar. Co., 324 S.C. 639, 644, 478 S.E.2d 868, 871 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Irregularities not involving jurisdiction do not render a judgment void.Â  Thomas & Howard Co., 318 S.C. at 291, 457 S.E.2d at 343. 
Although SLED does not directly challenge the circuit courtâ€™s specific power to expunge under the statute, SLED argues the court lacked subject matter jurisdiction in this case because of the statuteâ€™s prohibition against more than one expungement.Â  We disagree.Â  Subject matter jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong.Â  State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 100, 610 S.E.2d 494, 498 (2005).Â  The circuit court clearly had subject matter jurisdiction over Fryerâ€™s petition.Â  Because the court had subject matter jurisdiction, SLED should have directly appealed the 2000 order.Â  â€œThere is a wide difference between a want of jurisdiction in which case the court has no power to adjudicate at all, and a mistake in the exercise of undoubted jurisdiction in which case the action of the trial court is not void although it may be subject to direct attack on appeal.â€Â  Thomas & Howard Co., 318 S.C. at 291, 457 S.E.2d at 343.Â  When a court acts with proper subject matter jurisdiction, but takes action outside of its authority, the party against whom the act is done must object and directly appeal.Â  Coon v. Coon, 356 S.C. 342, 347-48, 588 S.E.2d 624, 627 (Ct. App. 2003), affâ€™d as modified, 364 S.C. 563, 614 S.E.2d 616 (2005).
SLED next argues the trial court erred in granting mandamus in the 2004 order.Â  SLED argues mandamus was neither requested nor deserved.Â  We find SLED has failed to preserve this issue.Â  A post-trial motion must be made when the trial court either grants relief not requested or rules on an issue not raised at trial. Â Pelican Bldg. Ctrs. of Horry-Georgetown, Inc. v. Dutton, 311 S.C. 56, 60, 427 S.E.2d 673, 675 (1993).
SLED finally argues the trial court erred in finding res judicata and estoppel applied to SLEDâ€™s challenge of the 2000 order because there was no litigation prior to the issuance of the 2000 order.Â  Based on our finding that the 2000 order was not void and SLED did not appeal the order, we decline to reach the issues of res judicata and estoppel.Â  
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the order on appeal is
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]  Section 22-5-910 provides, inter alia, for the expungement of first offense convictions in magistrate court, after three years, provided the defendant has no other conviction during the three-year period.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 22-5-910 (Supp. 2005) (amended).Â  â€œNo person may have his records expunged under this section more than once.â€Â  Id.

title: Companion Property and Casualty Insurance v. Airborne Express
description: Affirms the circuit court grant of summary judgment on the basis that under Georgia law an insurer under a commercial liability policy has no legal obligation to defend various negligence claims arising out of an intentional act committed by an employee of the insured company.
text:
Companion


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Companion Property and Casualty Insurance Company,
Respondent,
v.
Airborne Express, Inc., Moore Express, Inc., and Charles Carpenter, as personal representative of the estate of Jessica Lynne Carpenter,
Defendants,
Of whom Airborne Express, Inc. and Charles Carpenter, as personal representative of the estate of Jessica Lynne Carpenter, are the
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4124
Heard May 9, 2006 â€“ Filed June 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Robin A. Braithwaite, of Aiken, and Jonathan M. Aldeman, of Atlanta, Georgia, for Appellant Airborne Express; Ronald A. Maxwell, of Aiken, and James L. Ford, Sr., of Atlanta, Georgia, for Appellant Charles Carpenter.Â  
Karl Stephen Brehmer, of Columbia, and Marvin D. Dikeman and Melissa C. Patton, both of Atlanta, Georgia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Airborne Express, Inc. and Charles Carpenter appeal the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment in favor of Companion Property and Casualty Insurance Company in this declaratory judgment action.Â  We affirm.
This case arises from the tragic sexual assault and murder of Carpenterâ€™s daughter, seventeen-year-old Jessica Carpenter. Â Robert Franklin Atkins was employed by Moore Express, Inc., a package delivery sub-contractor for Airborne.Â  In late July of 2000, Atkins, a convicted felon, delivered a package to the Carpenter home.Â  He returned to the home on August 4th dressed in his Airborne uniform and driving an Airborne delivery vehicle, gained entry to the premises, and attacked Jessica.Â  
Carpenter, in his capacity as Jessicaâ€™s personal representative, filed a wrongful death and survival action against Airborne, Moore, and Atkins.Â  Moore was insured by Companion under a commercial general liability policy.[1]Â  Airborne was named as an additional insured.Â  Companion filed a declaratory judgment action contending that under the terms of the policy it was not required to defend Airborne or Moore because Jessicaâ€™s murder was not an â€œoccurrenceâ€ as contemplated by the terms of the policy, and, further, fell within the intentional acts exclusion of the policy.Â  The trial court agreed and granted summary judgment in Companionâ€™s favor.Â  Airborne and Carpenter appeal.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing a motion for summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard of review as the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP.Â  Cowburn v. Leventis, 360 S.C. 20, 30, 619 S.E.2d 437, 443 (Ct. App. 2005) (citing Trousdell v. Cannon, 351 S.C. 636, 639, 572 S.E.2d 264, 265 (2002)).Â  Summary judgment should be affirmed if there is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Id.Â  â€œOur standard of review in evaluating a motion for summary judgment is to liberally construe the record in favor of the nonmoving party and give the nonmoving party the benefit of all favorable inferences that might reasonably be drawn therefrom.â€Â  Estes v. Roper Temp. Servs., Inc., 304 S.C. 120, 121, 403 S.E.2d 157, 158 (Ct. App. 1991). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Airborne appeals the trial courtâ€™s determination that Carpenterâ€™s complaint failed to allege an â€œoccurrenceâ€ within the contemplation of the terms of the policy and that the intentional acts exclusion of the policy precludes coverage.[2]Â  Carpenter contends the court improperly applied the summary judgment standard by finding inferences in favor of the moving party, Companion.Â  
As a preliminary matter, we must determine which stateâ€™s law applies.Â  In construing insurance policies, South Carolina courts apply the law of the state where the policy was issued.Â  Gordon v. Colonial Ins. Co. of California, 342 S.C. 152, 155-56, 536 S.E.2d 376, 378 (2000).Â  Moore is a Georgia corporation, and the policy was issued and delivered to Moore in Georgia.Â  Consequently, Georgia law governs our application and interpretation of the policy.Â  All parties agree the application of Georgia law is appropriate.
An insurerâ€™s duty to defend is determined by examining the allegations contained in the complaint and comparing them to the coverage provided by the policy.Â  Batson-Cooke Co. v. Aetna Ins. Co., 409 S.E.2d 41, 42-43 (Ga. App. 1991).Â  In the instant case, the underlying complaint states claims for wrongful death and survival.Â  In stating his claims, Carpenter alleges that Airborne and Moore were negligent in failing to conduct a background investigation of Atkins prior to hiring him, in failing to warn customers that delivery persons had not been subject to background checks, in failing to conduct periodic background checks once employees were hired, and in inducing customers to believe that delivery persons are agents and representatives of Airborne, all resulting in Atkinsâ€™ assault of Jessica.Â  
The initial allegation, that Airborne and Moore were negligent in Atkinsâ€™ assault of Jessica, appears to rest solely on the theory of vicarious liability; i.e., the employeeâ€™s conduct is imputed to his employer.Â  The remaining allegations, however, seem to assert separate negligent acts or omissions on the part of Airborne and Moore that contributed to Jessicaâ€™s assault and death.Â  Having preliminarily examined the allegations in the complaint, we must now compare those allegations with the coverage provided by the relevant provisions in the policy.
Mooreâ€™s CGL policy provides the following:

This insurance applies to â€œbodily injuryâ€ or â€œproperty damageâ€ only if:
  
    
      
        
          (1)   
          The â€œbodily injuryâ€ or â€œproperty damageâ€ is caused by an â€œoccurrenceâ€ that takes place in the â€œcoverage territory[.]â€ Â 
        
      
    
  

Occurrence is defined in the policy as â€œan accident, including continuous or repeated exposure to substantially the same general harmful conditions.â€Â  Airborne argues that whether Jessicaâ€™s murder was an â€œaccidentâ€ must be viewed not from Atkinsâ€™ standpoint, but from the standpoint of Airborne and Moore under the Georgia case of Crook v. Georgia Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co., 428 S.E.2d 802 (Ga. App. 1993).Â  In Crook, the son of the plaintiffs in the underlying suit committed an intentional act that resulted in his death.Â  Id. at 802-03.Â  The parents sued Crook, who was characterized as an innocent bystander, apparently on the theory that he should have intervened to prevent the son from suffering the fatal consequence of his own voluntary act.Â  Id.Â  Crook was insured under a homeownerâ€™s policy issued by Georgia Farm Bureau, which defended under a reservation of rights and brought a declaratory judgment action asserting it owed no duty to defend because the sonâ€™s death was the result of an intentional act on his part.Â  Id. at 803.Â  The sonâ€™s death was therefore not an â€œoccurrenceâ€ as defined by the policy terms.Â  Id. The Georgia Court of Appeals determined that although the sonâ€™s intentional act caused his own death, as to Crook, who was the insured and apparently took no active role in the occurrence that caused the sonâ€™s death, the event was â€œclearly an â€˜accident,â€™ because it was an unintentional event which took place without [Crookâ€™s] â€˜foresight or expectation or design.â€™â€Â  Id. Â Â The court insinuated that the underlying tort action could be considered â€œgroundless,â€ but that had no bearing on the decision whether Farm Bureau owed Crook the duty of providing him a defense.Â  Id.
Even if Crook supports the notion that an intentional act committed by one party may be considered an accident as to an insured in certain circumstances, it does not support Airborneâ€™s main contention.Â  In Crook, the intentional act causing the ultimate event complained of was committed by a total stranger to the policy, and such act was not attributable, either vicariously or otherwise, to the insured.Â  To interpret Crook to mean that the intentional acts of Atkins are completely severable from Moore and Airborne would require us to disregard other more recent, and more on point, precedents.
Subsequent Georgia case law appears to support the conclusion urged upon us by Companion that, because Atkinsâ€™ acts were clearly intentional, the claims by Carpenter are not covered.[3]Â  Oâ€™Dell v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co., 478 S.E.2d 418 (Ga. App. 1996), is a coverage case that arose as a result of an employeeâ€™s suit against the employer, Oâ€™Dell, and his two companies,
DRACS Consulting Group, Inc. (DRACS) and Direct Recruiting Associates (DRA), for sexual harassment and assault and battery.Â  Id. at 419.Â  The court determined that the sexual harassment claims did not constitute â€œbodily injuryâ€ as required by the policy, and the assault and battery did not constitute an event under the policy as such acts were clearly intentional and not accidental.Â  Id. at 420.Â  Most significantly, the court went on to address potential negligence claims against DRACS and DRA arising from the underlying assault and battery and sexual harassment claims.

Oâ€™Dell also claims that St. Paul must defend the lawsuit on behalf of DRACS and DRA because [plaintiff] alleged facts on which a cause of action for negligent retention of Oâ€™Dell could be based.Â  We note initially that the policy does not recite that it covers losses due to negligent retention.Â  But even if this were true, the complaint does not allege that [plaintiff] suffered bodily injuries, and even assuming she did suffer bodily injuries, she did not allege that those injuries were caused by an accident and thus were brought about by an â€œevent.â€ Â 

Id.Â  (emphasis in original).
We find the factual scenario in Oâ€™Dell so similar to those in the instant case that we consider the holding therein to be controlling here.Â  In Oâ€™Dell, the plaintiff alleged an intentional tort, sexual harassment, and brought a claim of negligent retention against DRACS and DRA.Â  The Georgia Court of Appeals concluded that the negligent retention claim specifically was not a covered â€œeventâ€ under the CGL policy because the plaintiff did not allege her injuries were caused by an accident.Â  
In this case, the plaintiff has alleged intentional acts, assault and murder, and has asserted a negligence claim against Moore and Airborne.Â  We are compelled to conclude, as did the court in Oâ€™Dell, that the negligence claims against Airborne do not constitute an â€œoccurrence,â€ as Carpenter does not allege Jessicaâ€™s injuries were caused by an accident.Â  As a result, the claims against Airborne are not covered under the policy.Â  
The decision of the Eleventh Circuit in SCI Liquidating Corp. v. Hartford Fire Ins. Co., 181 F.3d 1210 (1999), supports our interpretation of Oâ€™Dell by stating, â€œ[t]he Georgia Court [in Oâ€™Dell] concluded that the plaintiffâ€™s negligent retention claims also were not covered, because, among other things, the plaintiff â€˜did not allege that those injuries were caused by an accident and thus were brought about by an â€˜event.â€™â€Â  Id. at 1216.Â  The court in SCI Liquidating also declined to rely on Crook recognizing, as we do, a distinction between Crook and cases like the one before us.Â  See id. at 1216-17.
Because we conclude Carpenterâ€™s complaint does not allege an occurrence under the policy, thereby negating Companionâ€™s obligation to defend, we decline to address whether the policyâ€™s intentional act exclusion is applicable.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR; Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 498, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (â€œ[A]n appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is dispositive.â€).Â  
AFFIRMED.
 HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] 
Moore also had a commercial automobile policy through Companion, and both Moore and Airborne sought coverage under that policy as well.Â  Coverage under that policy is not an issue in this appeal.
[2] 
Airborne and Carpenter also contend that the cases relied upon by Companion are factually distinct from this case.Â  As that question is essentially part and parcel of the central issue on appeal, we do not address it separately.
[3] 
The policy at issue also contains a â€œseparation of insuredsâ€ clause that indicates each insured will be treated severally under the policy.Â  Had this issue been sufficiently preserved by having been raised to and ruled upon by the trial court, this case would potentially require a different analysis.Â  See State v. Dunbar, 356 S.C. 138, 142, 587 S.E.2d 691, 693-94 (2003) (holding that an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review).
