title: Wright v. Dickey
description: This case presents the issue of whether this court has jurisdiction to review a decision of the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board that has been appealed to the circuit court.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Hiesha Wright, Respondent,
v.
James H. Dickey, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Florence County
Â Edward B. Cottingham, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4126
Submitted June 1, 2006 â€“ Filed June 19, 2006
Withdrawn, Substituted, and Refiled September 11, 2006Â Â Â 

APPEAL DISMISSED


  
    
      
James H. Dickey, of Atlanta, for Appellant. 
Kevin Mitchell Barth, of Florence, for Respondent.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  We are presented with an appeal from a decision of the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board of the South Carolina Bar.Â  We dismiss this appeal and hold that this court lacks appellate jurisdiction to review such matters.[1]Â  
I.
Hiesha Wright retained Dickey in February of 2001 to advise her in certain legal matters.Â  She paid Dickey for his services.Â  According to Wright, Dickey failed to perform the work and refused to return the fee.Â  Wright filed an application with the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board of the South Carolina Bar (Board).Â  Having submitted the fee dispute to the Board, Wright bound herself and Dickey (as a member of the South Carolina Bar) to the decision of the Board.Â  See Rule 416, SCACR, Rule 9.Â  
In compliance with Rule 416, SCACR, the matter was referred to the circuit chair and assigned to an investigator.Â  Dickey initially cooperated with the inquiry, but subsequently refused to communicate with the Boardâ€™s investigator.Â  The investigation yielded a recommendation that Dickey return a portion of the retainer to Wright.Â  
The circuit chair reviewed, and ultimately concurred with, the recommendation.Â  Because the amount in dispute was less than $5,000, the circuit chairâ€™s concurrence represented the final decision of the Board.Â  Rule 416, SCACR, Rule 13.Â  
On October 8, 2002, Dickey appealed to the circuit court pursuant to Rule 20 of the Rules of the Board, but set forth no grounds for the appeal.Â  Dickeyâ€™s notice of appeal stated that the grounds for the appeal would be included in his â€œforthcomingâ€ brief.Â  Despite repeated requests that he do so, Dickey never filed a brief in regards to this matter, and did not assert any specific grounds for relief.Â  Dickey attempted to state his grounds for appellate review after the matter was heard in the circuit court.
After continuances at Dickeyâ€™s request, the case was called for a hearing on March 2, 2004, before Judge B. Hicks Harwell.Â  Dickey attended this hearing.Â  Because Wright appeared pro se, Judge Harwell granted 15 days for Wright to retain counsel.Â  Judge Harwell subsequently recused himself.Â  The Chief Justice of the South Carolina Supreme Court issued an order reassigning the matter to Judge Edward B. Cottingham.Â  
The hearing was rescheduled for April 5, 2004, and Dickey was properly notified by certified mail.Â  Dickey knew of this hearing, for he again requested a continuance.Â  Dickey failed to appear at the hearing.Â  As noted, Dickey failed to file a brief or memorandum specifying the grounds for his appeal.Â  The circuit court entered an order dismissing the appeal with prejudice.Â  
Dickey filed a motion to alter or amend, contending that he did not receive proper notice of the hearing, and that the circuit court judge erred in refusing to recuse himself from the case.Â  The circuit court denied the motion, finding that: (1) Dickey received proper notice and willfully failed to attend the hearing; and (2) Dickey never filed a motion requesting recusal and failed to provide any evidence of a conflict of interest or other reason requiring recusal.Â  This appeal followed. 
II.
We find this court lacks jurisdiction to review this appeal.Â  Rule 201(a), SCACR, provides that appeals â€œmay be taken, as provided by law, from any final judgment or appealable order.â€Â  (Emphasis added.) Â Â In the civil arena, â€œ[t]he right of appeal arises from and is controlled by statutory law.â€Â  N.C. Fed. Sav. & Loan Assâ€™n v. Twin States Dev. Corp., 289 S.C. 480, 481, 347 S.E.2d 97, 97 (1986).Â  
The criteria for determining appealability are set forth in sections 14-3-320 and -330 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005).Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 18-9-10 (Supp. 2005).Â  Section 14-3-320 provides for appellate jurisdiction in equity cases.[2]Â  Section 14-3-330 provides that appellate courts â€œshall have appellate jurisdiction for correction of errors of law in law cases . . . .â€Â  We are not, however, presented with a typical action at law or equity, but a specialized proceeding before a branch of the South Carolina Bar, which in turn is an administrative arm of the South Carolina Supreme Court.
The case of Kores Nordic (USA) Corp. v. Sinkler, Gibbs & Simons, 284 S.C. 513, 327 S.E.2d 365 (Ct. App. 1985), is instructive.Â  Kores Nordic submitted a fee dispute with the Sinkler law firm to the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board.Â  Id. at 514, 327 S.E.2d at 365.Â  At the time, the applicable rules did not provide for any appeal of the Boardâ€™s decision.Â  Dissatisfied with the decision of the Board, Kores Nordic sought an appeal to the circuit court under the Administrative Procedures Act (APA).Â  The circuit court dismissed the attempted appeal, and this court affirmed.Â  The APA â€œrequires as a prerequisite to judicial review that a final decision in a contested case have been rendered by an â€˜agency.â€™â€Â  Id. at 515, 327 S.E.2d at 366.Â  We held that the Board, as part of the South Carolina Bar (and hence our supreme court), was not an â€œagencyâ€ within the ambit of the APA.Â  Id. at 516, 327 S.E.2d at 366.Â  
Subsequent to our opinion in Kores Nordic, Rule 416 was amended to provide for a limited right of appeal to the circuit court.Â  The rule (Rule 20 within SCACR Rule 416) provides that a party may appeal a final decision of the Board to the circuit court on certain limited grounds.Â  No mention is made of further appeal.Â  Indeed, further appeal runs contrary to the Boardâ€™s purpose of expeditious resolution of fee disputes.Â  See Rule 416, SCACR, Rule 2 (â€œThe purpose of the Board is to establish procedures whereby a dispute concerning fees . . . may be resolved expeditiously . . . .â€); Byrd v. Irmo High Sch., 321 S.C. 426, 433-34, 468 S.E.2d 861, 865 (1996) (recognizing that where a statute specifically sets forth an appeals procedure, we may not expand our jurisdiction through implication).
III.
We conclude there is no appeal from a decision of the Resolution of Fee Disputes Board of the South Carolina Bar beyond the circuit court as set forth in Rule 416, SCACR, Rule 20.Â  This appeal is
DISMISSED.
SHORT and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] 
We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] 
Section 14-3-320 has been declared unconstitutional to the extent it purports to limit the scope of appellate review in domestic cases.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 204, 414 S.E.2d 157, 160 (1992).

title: State v. Santiago
description: Christopher Santiago appeals his convictions for murder and possesion of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, alleging the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the jury on self-defense and in excluding testimony of a forensic psychiatrist.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Christopher Alan Santiago, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4127
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed June 19, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Richard A. Harpootlian and M. David Scott, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor RandolphÂ  Murdaugh, III, of Hampton, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Christopher Santiago appeals his convictions of murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime, alleging the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the jury on self-defense and in excluding testimony of a forensic psychiatrist.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
During the summer of 2002, Santiago and Kate Wisn lived together at the Hilton Head vacation home of Kateâ€™s parents.Â  When Kateâ€™s father, Joe (hereinafter â€œWisnâ€), visited Hilton Head in July, he informed Santiago that he and Kate needed to move out of the home within the next two weeks.Â  That evening, Santiago left the home and drove to New Jersey to live with his parents.Â  After a brief stay in New Jersey, Santiago returned to South Carolina and began renting an apartment near the vacation home.Â  
According to Santiago, on the morning of August 9, 2002, he left his apartment with a 20-gauge shotgun in the trunk of his car with the intent to commit suicide.Â Â  Before taking his own life, he called his parents to tell them goodbye.Â  They convinced him to see his psychiatrist, who was able to talk Santiago out of committing suicide. [1] 
When Santiago returned to his apartment, he had a message on his answering machine from Wisn, requesting that Santiago come to the vacation home to pick up some belongings.Â  Upon his arrival at Wisnâ€™s home, Santiago saw his belongings packed in a container beside Wisnâ€™s car in the driveway.Â  Santiago rummaged through the container in search of a favorite belt but was unable to find it.Â  He rang the doorbell; Wisn answered, and the two men went inside to search for the belt.Â  
According to Santiago, he began to cry while looking for the belt, and Wisn ridiculed him.Â  At that point Santiago left the house, but Wisn followed him.Â  Santiago testified that Wisn told him to â€œstay the fâ€” away from my daughter.â€ Â Santiago walked past the container of his belongings, but Wisn picked it up and walked around to the back of Santiagoâ€™s car to place it in the trunk.Â  After Santiago opened the trunk, Wisn placed the container into it and noticed the 20-gauge shotgun.Â  Wisn looked at the shotgun, looked at Santiago, and then looked at the shotgun again.Â  Santiago testified he thought Wisn was about to grab the shotgun, so he took the gun from the trunk and pointed it at Wisn.Â Â Â  Santiago took a step back.Â  Wisn told Santiago â€œdonâ€™t be fâ€”ing stupid.â€ Â Santiago testified he thought Wisn was about to reach for the gun so he opened fire.Â  He shot Wisn four times, and Wisn later died from his wounds.Â  
After fleeing the scene, Santiago drove to a fire station, and told the firemen that he shot someone on Hilton Head who had â€œruined his life.â€Â  Â Â A fireman called the police, and the police sent detective Leland Tuten to investigate.Â  Detective Tuten provided Santiago with a Miranda [2]  rights and waiver form, which Santiago initialed and signed.Â  Tuten then provided Santiago with a pen and paper, and Santiago drafted a confession.Â  In this confession, Santiago explained that while he lived with Kate, Wisn tried to turn her family members against him.Â  He wrote he planned to marry Kate, but his plan fell through because Wisn kicked him out of the house.Â  Santiago also admitted he shot Wisn four times with the shotgun.Â  The confession went on to describe the shooting.Â  Santiago said he was standing near the back of his car when he fired on Wisn, who was standing near the front of the car. [3] Â  After Santiago confessed to the shooting, Tuten arrested him. Santiago was subsequently indicted for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  
During trial, Santiago attempted to present testimony from Dr. Donna Schwartz-Watts, a forensic psychiatrist, who, prior to trial, had diagnosed Santiago with a condition called aspergerâ€™s disorder, a subset of autism.Â  Santiago argued Schwartz-Wattsâ€™s testimony would be relevant to his mental state at the time of the shooting and would also support a finding that Santiago committed voluntary manslaughter rather than murder.Â  The trial judge refused to allow her testimony into evidence, finding it was not relevant because South Carolina does not recognize the defense of diminished capacity.Â  The trial court also rejected Santiagoâ€™s request to charge the jury with self-defense.Â Â Â  
The jury convicted Santiago of murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a crime.Â  The judge sentenced Santiago to life imprisonment without parole.Â  Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Self-Defense Charge 
Santiago first argues the trial judge erred in refusing to charge the jury on self-defense.Â  We disagree. 
An appellate court will not reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision regarding jury charges absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 389, 529 S.E.2d 528, 539 (2000); State v. Williams, 367 S.C. 192, 624 S.E.2d 443 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  If there is any evidence to support a jury charge, the trial judge should grant the requested charge.Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 262, 513 S.E.2d 104, 108 (1999).Â  The refusal to grant a requested jury charge that states a sound principle of law applicable to the case at hand is an error of law.Â  Clark, 339 S.C. at 390, 529 S.E.2d at 539.Â  To warrant a reversal, however, the error must result in prejudice to the party requesting the charge.Â  Id.Â  A self-defense charge is not required unless the evidence supports it.Â  State v. Goodson, 312 S.C. 278, 280, 440 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1994).Â  
To establish self defense in South Carolina, four elements must be present: (1) the defendant was without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2) the defendant actually believed he was in imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) a reasonable, prudent person of ordinary fitness and courage would have entertained the same belief; and (4) the defendant had no other probable means of avoiding the danger of losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury other than to act as he did.Â  Jackson v. State, 355 S.C. 568, 570-71, 586 S.E.2d 562, 562 (2003); State v. Day, 341 S.C. 410, 416, 535 S.E.2d 431, 434 (2000).Â  If there is any evidence of self-defense, the issue must be submitted to the jury.Â  State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 260, 565 S.E.2d 298, 302 (2002).Â  In charging self-defense, the trial judge should consider the facts and circumstances of the case and fashion an appropriate charge.Â  State v. Starnes, 340 S.C. 312, 322, 531 S.E.2d 907, 913 (2000).Â  The trial judge commits reversible error if he or she fails to give a charge on an issue raised by the evidence and requested by the defendant.Â  State v. Lee, 298 S.C. 362, 364, 380 S.E.2d 834, 836 (1989).Â Â Â  
Here, the record does not support a charge of self-defense for several reasons.Â  First, the evidence does not support a finding that Santiago was without fault in bringing about the difficulty.Â  Santiago had gone to Wisnâ€™s house with a loaded gun in his vehicle, and that weapon was apparently observed by Wisn as he lifted Santiagoâ€™s belongings into the car.Â  Although Santiago asserted that Wisn verbally berated him as he looked for his favorite belt, these words were never accompanied by a hostile act.Â  While we recognize that, depending on the circumstances, words accompanied by hostile acts may establish self-defense, there was no evidence of a hostile act by Wisn.Â  See State v. Fuller, 297 S.C. 440, 444, 377 S.E.2d 328, 331 (1989); State v. Harvey, 220 S.C. 506, 518, 68 S.E.2d 409, 414 (1951) (â€œ[W]here death is caused by the use of a deadly weapon, words alone, however opprobrious, are not sufficient to constitute a legal provocation.â€).Â  
Santiago argues the hostile act occurred when Wisn looked at the gun, looked at Santiago, and then looked at the gun again.Â  This bare assertion is insufficient to establish a hostile act by Wisn. Â Santiago never claimed Wisn made a move for the gun before Santiago took it from the trunk.Â  Even assuming, as Santiago testified, that Wisn reached for the gun while in Santiagoâ€™s hands, he did so after Santiago brought about the difficulty by removing the shotgun from the trunk and aiming it at Wisn.[4]Â  Therefore, no question of fact for the jury is created on the first prong of self-defense.Â  
While Santiago asserts he actually believed he was in imminent danger, the third prong of self-defense cannot be established because a reasonable, prudent person of ordinary fitness and courage would not have feared for his life or serious bodily injury under the circumstances of this case.Â  Santiago testified that he and Wisn had never had a physical altercation, nor had Wisn ever threatened to kill or cause serious injury to Santiago before the shooting.Â  Additionally, the evidence, taken in the light most favorable to Santiago, demonstrates that Wisn merely looked at the shotgun, looked at Santiago, and then looked at the shotgun again.Â  Accordingly, no reasonable person would have feared for his life simply because of Wisnâ€™s actions of looking.Â  Therefore, no question of fact for the jury is created on this element of self-defense.Â Â Â Â Â  
Finally, the fourth prong of self-defense cannot be satisfied because Santiago had other probable means of avoiding the danger.Â  If the defendant provokes or initiates the assault, he cannot invoke self-defense; however, he may restore his right to self-defense if he withdraws from the conflict and communicates that decision to his adversary.Â  State v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 345, 520 S.E.2d 319, 322 (1999).Â  Because Santiago was not on his property, he had a duty to retreat.Â  See Fuller, 297 S.C. at 444, 377 S.E.2d at 331.Â  Taken in the light most favorable to Santiago, the record indicates that when Wisn was shot, Santiago stood at the back of his car and Wisn stood in the front. Â Due to the distance between the two men at the time of the shooting, Santiago could have retreated with the shotgun rather than shooting Wisn.Â  Moreover, Santiago simply could have avoided the danger by closing his trunk.Â  See Bryant, 336 S.C. at 345, 520 S.E.2d at 322 (stating appellant easily could have avoided the conflict by leaving the open parking lot where the situation arose).Â  Further, because Wisn was unarmed, Santiago had multiple opportunities to escape his perceived peril without resorting to firing his weapon, let alone firing it four times.Â  Therefore, no question of fact for the jury is created on this prong of self-defense.Â  
Because the record demonstrates as a matter of law the absence of at least one element of self-defense, the trial judge did not err in refusing to charge self-defense.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Dr. Schwartz-Wattsâ€™s TestimonyÂ  
Santiago next argues the trial judge erred in refusing to allow Schwartz-Watts to testify that because of Santiagoâ€™s aspergerâ€™s disorder he did not have the requisite mental state to commit murder nor the ability to provide a voluntary confession.Â  Santiago attempted to call Schwartz-Watts as a witness during his case, but the trial judge refused to allow the testimony.Â  We find no reversible error.
The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 557, 564 S.E.2d 87, 93 (2002); State v. Horton, 359 S.C. 555, 566, 598 S.E.2d 279, 285 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  A trial judgeâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Mansfield, 343 S.C. 66, 77, 538 S.E.2d 257, 263 (Ct. Tennessee, 322 U.S. 143, 64 S.Ct. 921, 88 L.Ed. 1192; and the use of physical punishment such as the deprivation of food or sleep, e.g., Reck v. Pate, 367 U.S. 433, 81 S.Ct. 1541, 6 L.Ed.2d 948. Â In all of these cases, the Court determined the factual circumstances surrounding the confession, assessed the psychological impact on the accused, and evaluated the legal significance of how the accused reacted. Culombe v. Connecticut, supra, 367 U.S., at 603, 81 S.Ct., at 1879.â€) (footnote omitted).
The appellate entities of South Carolina have recognized that appropriate factors include: background, experience, and conduct of the accused; age; length of custody; police misrepresentations; isolation of a minor from his or her parent; threats of violence; and promises of leniency.Â  See Childs, 299 S.C. at 475, 385 S.E.2d at 842 (background, experience, and conduct of the accused); In re Williams, 265 S.C. 295, 217 S.E.2d 719 (1975) (age); State v. Jennings, 280 S.C. 62, 309 S.E.2d 759 (1983) (length of custody); State v. Rabon, 275 S.C. 459, 461, 272 S.E.2d 634, 635 (1980) (police misrepresentations); State v. Smith, 268 S.C. 349, 355, 234 S.E.2d 19, 21 (1977) (isolation of minor); State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 200, 391 S.E.2d 244, 246 (1990) (threats of violence and promises of leniency). 
Furthermore, our courts have recognized the relevance of a factor which is crucial to the determination of this case: the mental state of the accused.Â  
In State v. Cain, 246 S.C. 536, 144 S.E.2d 905 (1965), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991) (abrogating the doctrine of in favorem vitae), Hershel Cain was convicted of murder and sentenced to death.Â  The victim, who owned a grocery store and filling station, was found lying on the floor of his store, dead from a gunshot wound to the chest.Â  Police arrested Cain two days later and he confessed to the murder.Â  The officer who took Cainâ€™s statement testified to the facts surrounding the confession.Â  â€œ[A]t the time the confession was admitted in evidence, the sole testimony before the trial Judge was that such confession had been freely and voluntarily made by the appellant.Â  There was no testimony to the contrary.â€Â  246 S.C. at 539, 144 S.E.2d at 906.Â  However, prior to the shooting, a doctor diagnosed Cain with a mental conditionâ€”â€œschizophrenic reaction of the paranoid type.â€Â  Id.Â  Cain contended

that the court should have excluded from the evidence the statement or confession signed by the appellant because the appellant, at the time of the making of said confession, was a suspect, was under arrest, and was not provided with counsel; and that at the time of the making of said confession, the appellant was disoriented, having been a patient in the State Hospital prior to the alleged confession and again within five days after making such confession.

246 S.C. at 541, 144 S.E.2d at 907.Â  The court found that the confession was admissible, but reversed Cainâ€™s convictions because the judge failed to charge the jury as to its role in determining the voluntariness of Cainâ€™s confession.

At the time the confession of the appellant was offered and admitted into evidence, even though the confession was taken while the appellant was in custody, all of the evidence showed that the said confession, as made, was a free and voluntary one, and there was no evidence to contradict the prima facie showing made by the State.Â  State v. Sharpe, 239 S.C. 258, 122 S.E.2d 622.Â  The lack of mental capacity is an important factor to be considered with other factors in determining whether, in fact, a purported confession was voluntary.Â  Blackburn v. State of Alabama, 361 U.S. 199, 80 S.Ct. 274, 4 L.Ed.2d 242.Â  The appellant had the right to introduce evidence of his insanity at the time of his confession for the purpose of impairing or destroying its effect and it was for the jury to determine what weight should be accorded thereto.Â  We think the confession was admissible in evidence.
. . . . 
The record in this case shows that the trial Judge failed to give any instructions whatsoever as to the rules governing confessions.Â  We think this was prejudicial error.Â  The question of whether the appellant was mentally capable of making a confession and understood the contents of his statement and freely and voluntarily executed it should have been submitted to the jury under appropriate instructions.Â  State v. Gardner, 219 S.C. 97, 64 S.E.2d 130, and State v. Clinkscales, 231 S.C. 650, 99 S.E.2d 663.Â  We quote from the last cited case: 
  
â€˜Although all the evidence may be to the effect that a confession made while under arrest was a voluntary one, the jury may not be so convinced; and it is the jury who, in the final analysis, must determine the factual issue of voluntariness.Â  State v. Miller, 211 S.C. 306, 45 S.E.2d 23; State v. Gardner, 219 S.C. 97, 64 S.E.2d 130. Cf. State v. Harris, 212 S.C. 124, 46 S.E.2d 682.Â  Similarly, even though a jury accepts a written confession as having been voluntarily made, it is not thereby bound to accept every statement contained in it as true; for it is the sole judge of its credibility, and may believe it all, or in part, or not at all.Â  It is unreasonable to assume that these matters are within the knowledge of the average juror; he should be informed of them by the Court.Â  Whether such instruction would have altered the verdict in this case is a matter upon which we need not speculate; since life is at stake the case should be remanded, so that upon its retrial the jury may be instructed as to their power, as sole judges of the facts to determine whether or not, under the evidence, the confession was voluntary, and to what extent they will give it credence.â€™
  

We think that in all fairness to the trial Judge it should be stated that he was not requested to instruct the jury on the subject of confessions.Â  However, under the well recognized practice of this Court, where the death penalty is involved, these omissions on the part of counsel will not be held to waive the rights of the appellant.

 The judgment of the lower Court is reversed and this case remanded for a new trial.

Cain, 246 S.C. at 541-42, 144 S.E.2d at 907-08.
In State v. Callahan, 263 S.C. 35, 208 S.E.2d 284 (1974), Callahan confessed to rape, robbery, and burglary.Â  He was indicted, and a jury convicted him of all charges.Â  His confession was the basis for his appeal.Â  The trial judge heard in camera testimony from a psychiatrist, Dr. Forsthoefel, who â€œhad diagnosed the defendant as â€˜mental retardation moderate.â€™â€ Â Id.Â  at 39-40, 208 S.E.2d at 285.Â  Dr. Forsthoefel 

testified somewhat at length as to his ability to think and reason under stress.Â  He said that the defendant â€˜when subjected to even mild stress would become very labile, excitable and disorganized in his thinking and upset.â€™Â  He did not testify that the defendant did not know legal right from legal wrong.

263 S.C. at 40, 208 S.E.2d at 285.Â  Â Â Â Â Â  
After hearing additional testimony, the judge concluded Callahanâ€™s confession â€œâ€˜was freely and voluntarily made after the defendant had been accorded all of his Constitutional rights.â€™â€Â  263 S.C. at 40, 208 S.E.2d at 286.Â  The issue of voluntariness became a question of fact for the jury, and accordingly, the State and Callahan proceeded to offer testimony relating to the confession before the jury.Â  

  After the State had again submitted its witnesses on the voluntariness issue, and while counsel for the defendant was again presenting his witnesses to the contra, Dr. Forsthoefel was again called to the stand and testified.Â  He said that his diagnosis was that the defendant â€œis moderate mental retardation, I.Q. range of 55 to 65 at the most.â€
  

  The record then reflects the following:

â€œQ. Do you have an opinion as to his ability to think or reason under stress?

â€œA. Yes, I do have an opinion.â€ 
  
  The solicitor objected to this question and the judge sustained the objection. Later, defense counsel asked this question:
  
Â 
â€œQ. Okay, Doctor, do you have an opinion as to his quality of thinking?â€
Â 
Â â€œA. His quality of thinking . . .â€
  
 The trial judge interrupted and did not permit the witness to continue to answer.

263 S.C. at 40, 208 S.E.2d at 286.Â  Â Â Â Â Â  
The issue for the Callahan court was â€œwhether the defendant was prejudiced by denial of the right to further pursue the question of mental capacityâ€ in the juryâ€™s presence.Â  Id.Â  The court held the trial judge erred by refusing to allow the psychiatristâ€™s answers:

  A confession is not admissible unless voluntary, and it was for the jury to say in the last analysis whether the confession was or was not voluntary.Â  In State v. Cain, 246 S.C. 536, 144 S.E.2d 905 (1965), this Court held, â€œThe lack of mental capacity is an important factor to be considered with other factors in determining whether, in fact, a purported confession was voluntary.â€Â  Accordingly, the defendant was entitled to submit evidence of the psychiatrist touching on the defendantâ€™s mental capacity and it would have been appropriate to allow both questions quoted hereinabove.

263 S.C. at 41, 208 S.E.2d at 286.Â  However, the court found no prejudice from the error because the jury heard other testimony of Callahanâ€™s mentality.Â  Id. at 43, S.E.2d at 287 (â€œTo exclude the testimony of Dr. Forsthoefel was inconsistent with our reasoning in Cain, but we think that the jury was fully apprised of the fact that the defendant was of very low mentality short of insanity.â€).
In State v. Doby, 273 S.C. 704, 709, 258 S.E.2d 896, 899 (1979), our supreme court recalled, â€œâ€˜We have consistently held that mental deficiency alone is not sufficient to render a confession involuntary but that it is a factor to be considered along with all of the other attendant facts and circumstances in determining the voluntariness of the confession. State v. Cain, 246 S.C. 536, 144 S.E.2d 905; State v. Callahan, 263 S.C. 35, 208 S.E.2d 284.â€™Â  In Re Williams, 265 S.C. 295, 301, 217 S.E.2d 719, 722 (1975).â€Â  
Jennings, age twenty-two, confessed to burglarizing a home and killing the resident in State v. Jennings, 280 S.C. 62, 309 S.E.2d 759 (1983).Â  Jennings had a hearing deficiency and was described as â€œâ€˜mildlyâ€™ retarded.â€Â  Id. at 63, 309 S.E.2d at 759.Â  However, the record included testimony that â€œthe officers who questioned appellant were aware of the physical deficiencies and exercised caution to be sure that he could hear and understand the communications with him.â€Â  Id. at 63-64, 309 S.E.2d at 760.Â  The court considered Jenningsâ€™s condition and found his confession voluntary considering the totality of the circumstances.Â  

Neither the length of custody before the confession was made, nor the physical deficiencies of the appellant, were conclusive of the issues concerning the voluntariness of the confession, but were factors to be considered by the trial judge, along with the other testimony and circumstances, in determining the admissibility of the alleged confession. We find no basis upon which to disturb the findings of the trial judge that the confession was freely and voluntarily made.

Jennings, 280 S.C. at 64, 309 S.E.2d at 760.
5.Â  Relevance of Expert Testimony to the Voluntariness Analysis 
Indubitably, a defendantâ€™s mental capacity is a factor that may be considered both by the court in its Jackson v. Denno hearing analysis, and by the jury in its voluntariness determination.Â  Santiago sought to admit Schwartz-Wattsâ€™s testimony as a means of explaining â€œhis issuing a statement as he did based on his perceptions of his not being treated well, being messed with, his rights violated[.]â€Â  This testimony was relevant to Santiagoâ€™s mental condition at the time of the confession and would have had a tendency to make more probable the allegedly involuntary nature of Santiagoâ€™s confession.Â  As the ultimate arbiter of whether Santiagoâ€™s confession was voluntary, the jury was entitled to hear Schwartz-Wattsâ€™s testimony.Â  Therefore, the trial judge erred in excluding it.Â  
Moreover, the error prejudiced Santiago.Â  Because the trial judge excluded Schwartz-Wattsâ€™s testimony, Santiago was unable to present the jury with evidence relevant to the voluntariness of his confession.Â  Further, the jury was not apprised of Santiagoâ€™s mental capacity through other testimony.Â  Cf. Callahan, 263 S.C. at 42, 208 S.E.2d at 286 (finding error not prejudicial when the jury knew of the defendantâ€™s mental capacity through other testimony).Â  Thus, the error was inimical to Santiago. 
The trial judge erred by failing to give a self-defense charge and committed an abuse of discretion by excluding evidence relevant to the juryâ€™s voluntariness determination.Â  Accordingly, I VOTE to REVERSE Santiagoâ€™s convictions.Â  

[1] Santiago did not call his psychiatrist as a witness.
[2]Â  Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).
[3] According to the testimony of the forensic pathologist, the shots were fired from a distance of six to ten feet.
[4] Â This is not a case where Santiago was justified in using deadly force before his adversary could â€œget the drop on him.â€Â  In Starnes, 340 S.C. at 322, 531 S.E.2d at 913, and State v. Hendrix, 270 S.C. 653, 661, 244 S.E.2d 503, 507 (1978), the defendantâ€™s adversary was already armed, or the defendant believed his adversary was already armed, when the defendant fired.Â  Here, there is no indication that Wisn was armed or that Santiago believed otherwise. Â 
[5] 378 U.S. 368 (1964).

title: Shealy v. Doe
description: In this John Doe proceeding, Appellant avers the circuit judge erred in dismissing the Appellantâ€™s complaint for failure to comply with S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-170 (2002).
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Jason Shealy, Appellant,
v.
John Doe, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Hampton County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4128
Heard June 15, 2006 â€“ Filed June 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Ralph Shealy Kennedy, Jr., and Robert M. Cook, II, both of Batesburg-Leesville, for Appellant.
David Cooper Cleveland, Thomas J. Keaveny, II, and Bob J. Conley, all of Charleston, for Respondent. 
      
    
  

ANDERSON, J.: Jason Shealy appeals the trial courtâ€™s order dismissing his claim for uninsured motorist (UM) coverage, arguing the trial court erred in (1) finding Shealy failed to comply with the witness affidavit requirement of South Carolina Code Annotated section 38-77-170 (2002); and (2) refusing to treat a letter from Safeco Insurance Company as an admission against interest. Â We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On June 7, 2003, Eddie Bolin was driving a pickup truck owned by Dale Leaphart.Â  Shealy and Ronald Cromer sat in the bed of the truck. Â Bolin swerved abruptly, throwing Shealy and Cromer from the truck.Â  Shealy sustained serious injuries, including a fractured skull. Â Bolin later explained to Shealy and the police that he swerved to avoid hitting an unknown vehicle.Â  
Shealy filed a complaint against the unknown driver, John Doe, to recover against Safeco, Leaphartâ€™s UM carrier. Â Shealy submitted an affidavit, which he attached and incorporated into the complaint.Â  The affidavit states:

Personally appeared before me, Jason Shealy, who being duly sworn deposes and says as follows:
That he is Jason Shealy and that on or about June 7, 2003, he was a passenger in a pickup truck being driven by Eddie Bolin and, upon information and belief, owned by Dale Leaphart.Â  That the pickup truck was being driven on Highway 391 near Batesburg-Leesville, South Carolina.Â  That Eddie Bolin sharply, unexpectedly and suddenly swerved the truck near the entrance to Leaphart Acres, throwing the affiant and another passenger from the bed of the truck onto the roadway.Â  That the day following the incident the affiant was told by Eddie Bolin that an unknown vehicle and driver had come onto the roadway in the path of the truck causing Eddie Bolin to sharply and unexpectedly maneuver the truck he was driving to avoid a collision.
A FALSE STATEMENT CONCERNING THE FACTS CONTAINED IN THIS AFFIDAVIT MAY SUBJECT THE PERSON MAKING THE FALSE STATEMENT TO CRIMINAL PENALTIES AS PROVIDED BY LAW.

(Emphasis added.)Â  
Doe moved to dismiss Shealyâ€™s action or, alternatively, to change venue.Â  At the motions hearing, Shealy submitted the affidavit of Ronald Cromer, which contains identical language to Shealyâ€™s affidavit.Â  In addition, Shealy submitted a letter from Safeco to his attorney.Â  The letter explained:

[Safeco has] remained consistent in the lack of negligence and lack of liability of Mr. Eddie Bolin, the driver of the automobile in which your client was occupying [sic].Â  Mr. Bolinâ€™s lack of negligence is due to the phantom vehicle which pulled out in front of him and caused the accident . . . .

Shealy argued the letter was an admission against interest.Â  
The trial court granted Doeâ€™s motion to dismiss, recognizing its consideration of Cromerâ€™s affidavit and Safecoâ€™s letter converted Doeâ€™s motion to dismiss into one for summary judgment.Â  The court held Shealy failed to comply with the witness affidavit requirement of section 38-77-170(2).Â  Shealy filed a motion to reconsider, which the trial court denied.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Pursuant to Rule 12(b)(6), SCRCP, a defendant may make a motion to dismiss a complaint for â€œfailure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action.â€Â  Rule 12(b) additionally provides:

If, on a motion asserting the defense numbered (6) to dismiss for failure of the pleading to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action, matters outside the pleading are presented to and not excluded by the Court, the motion shall be treated as one for summary judgment and disposed of as provided in Rule 56[.]

In this case, the trial court considered Cromerâ€™s affidavit and the letter from Safeco before granting Doeâ€™s motion to dismiss.Â  Accordingly, we review the trial courtâ€™s order as if it were an appeal from a grant of summary judgment.
When reviewing a grant of summary judgment, the appellate court applies the same standard which governs the trial court under Rule 56(c), SCRCP: summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Houck v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Ins. Co., 366 S.C. 7, 11, 620 S.E.2d 326, 329 (2005);Â  Â Pittman v. Grand Strand Entmâ€™t, Inc., 363 S.C. 531, 611 S.E.2d 922 (2005); B & B Liquors, Inc. v. Oâ€™Neil, 361 S.C. 267, 603 S.E.2d 629 (Ct. App. 2004); see Rule 56(c), SCRCP (â€œThe judgment sought shall be rendered forthwith if the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€). Â In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Helms Realty, Inc. v. Gibson-Wall Co., 363 S.C. 334, 611 S.E.2d 485 (2005); Medical Univ. of South Carolina v. Arnaud, 360 S.C. 615, 602 S.E.2d 747 (2004); Rife v. Hitachi Constr. Mach. Co., Ltd., 363 S.C. 209, 609 S.E.2d 565 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Â Witness Affidavit Requirement
Shealy argues the trial court erred in holding the affidavits he submitted were insufficient to satisfy section 38-77-170(2) of the South Carolina Code Annotated (2002).Â  We disagree.
Section 38-77-170 provides:

If the owner or operator of any motor vehicle which causes bodily injury or property damage to the insured is unknown, there is no right of action or recovery under the uninsured motorist provision, unless:
  
(1) the insured or someone in his behalf has reported the accident to some appropriate police authority within a reasonable time, under all the circumstances, after its occurrence;
(2) the injury or damage was caused by physical contact with the unknown vehicle, or the accident must have been witnessed by someone other than the owner or operator of the insured vehicle; provided however, the witness must sign an affidavit attesting to the truth of the facts of the accident contained in the affidavit;
(3) the insured was not negligent in failing to determine the identity of the other vehicle and the driver of the other vehicle at the time of the accident.
  
 The following statement must be prominently displayed on the face of the affidavit provided in subitem (2) above: A FALSE STATEMENT CONCERNING THE FACTS CONTAINED IN THIS AFFIDAVIT MAY SUBJECT THE PERSON MAKING THE FALSE STATEMENT TO CRIMINAL PENALTIES AS PROVIDED BY LAW.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-170 (2002) (emphasis added).Â  â€œAn insured cannot recover uninsured motorist coverage unless the three conditions under Â§ 38-77-170 are met.â€Â  Miller v. Doe, 312 S.C. 444, 446, 441 S.E.2d 319, 320 (1994).
The primary rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and give effect to the intent of the legislature.Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  The first question of statutory interpretation is whether the statuteâ€™s meaning is clear on its face.Â  Wade v. Berkeley County, 348 S.C. 224, 229, 559 S.E.2d 586, 588 (2002); Eagle Container Co., LLC v. County of Newberry, 366 S.C. 611, 622, 622 S.E.2d 733, 738 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  
When a statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed, and this Court has no right to impose another meaning.Â  See Vaughn v. Bernhardt, 345 S.C. 196, 198, 547 S.E.2d 869, 870 (2001).Â  â€œ[T]he words of the statute must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.â€Â  Mun. Assâ€™n of S.C. v. AT&T Communications of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C. 576, 580, 606 S.E.2d 468, 470 (2004); see also Miller, 312 S.C. at 447, 441 S.E.2d at 321 (â€œIn determining the meaning of a statute, the terms used therein must be taken in their ordinary and popular meaning, nothing to the contrary appearing.â€).
Section 38-77-170(2) is clear on its face.Â  It expressly requires that someone other than the owner or operator of the insured vehicle witness the accident.Â  As stated in Wausau Underwriters Insurance Company v. Howser, 309 S.C. 269, 275, 422 S.E.2d 106, 110 (1992), â€œno physical contact with the unknown vehicle is necessary when a witness other than the owner or driver of the insured vehicle is able to attest to the facts of the accident.â€Â  (Emphasis added.)Â  See also Collins v. Doe, 352 S.C. 462, 470, 574 S.E.2d 739, 744 (2002) (â€œThe plain language of Â§ 38-77-170 requires that where the accident involves no physical contact between the insuredâ€™s vehicle and the unidentified vehicle, the accident â€˜must have been witnessed by someone other than the owner or operator of the insured vehicleâ€™ and the â€˜witness must sign an affidavit attesting to the truth of the facts of the accident contained therein.â€™â€).Â  Shealy asserts section 38-77-170(2) does not require the witness affidavit to be based on personal knowledge.Â  This argument directly contravenes the language of the statute.Â  Shealy submitted affidavits of two people who apparently did not witness the accident; their affidavits do not attest to facts they perceived, but merely restate the perceptions of the vehicleâ€™s operator. Â Thus, Shealy produced no evidence that someone other than Bolin, the operator of the insured vehicle, witnessed the accident.Â  Shealyâ€™s and Cromerâ€™s affidavits do not comply with this express directive.Â  
Shealyâ€™s interpretation of section 38-77-170(2) would totally eviscerate the statuteâ€™s efficacy as it would allow an owner or operator to inform any third-party of the facts of the accident and have that third-party swear out an affidavit as to the owner or operatorâ€™s version of the events.Â  In Collins, our supreme court elucidated that the â€œobvious purposeâ€ of the affidavit requirement of section 38-77-170(2) is â€œfraud prevention.â€Â  Collins, 352 S.C. at 470, 574 S.E.2d at 743.Â  Shealyâ€™s reading of the statute would circumvent the fraud-preventing function of subsection (2), rendering that section meaningless.Â  
According to Shealy, requiring the affiant to have witnessed the accident creates an unreasonably harsh result because a sleeping passenger or blind passenger injured by a John Doe driver might be precluded from recovery.Â  Yet the statute indubitably bars an operator and lone occupant of a vehicle from recovery where no contact is made with the unknown driver and where no one else witnesses the accident.Â  In both instances, the result is lamentable to the injured party, but mandated by the statute.Â  Section 38-77-170 demonstrates a policy decision by the legislature which balances the interest of parties injured in accidents with unknown drivers, with the interest of insurance companies in preventing fraudulent claims.Â  Where the legislature determines policy and promulgates a clear rule of law, there is no room for the courts to alter that decision.Â  Â 
Finally, Shealy contends the affidavits comply with Gilliland v. Doe, 357 S.C. 197, 592 S.E.2d 626 (2004), because the affidavits he submitted provide circumstantial evidence of the accident.Â  In Gilliland, two young men in a truck were closely pursuing Angel Gilliland.Â  As Gilliland sped up to get away from the truck, she lost control of her car and hit a tree.Â  The truck never made contact with Gillilandâ€™s vehicle.Â  A witness who was stopped at a nearby intersection testified that she â€œsaw the lights of two cars as the cars came around the curve,â€ and that â€œafter the accident, she saw the lights of the car behind Petitionerâ€™s â€˜arc through the fieldâ€™ as if it were making a U-turn.â€Â  357 S.C. at 198-99, 592 S.E.2d at 627.Â  A jury returned a verdict for Gilliland, but we held a witness â€œmust testify to more than the actual collision itself.Â  The witness must also be able to attest to the circumstances surrounding the accident, i.e. what actions of the unknown driver contributed to the accident.â€Â  Gilliland v. Doe, 351 S.C. 497, 501-02, 570 S.E.2d 545, 548 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Accordingly, we reversed the trial court and granted Doeâ€™s motion for a judgment notwithstanding the verdict.Â  However, the South Carolina Supreme Court reversed and reinstated the judgment of the trial court.Â  
The supreme court began with a historical review of the unknown driver statute:

The Legislature first enacted a â€œJohn Doeâ€ statute in 1963, recognizing an insuredâ€™s right to receive uninsured motorist coverage for injuries caused by unknown drivers. Since the statuteâ€™s enactment, the Legislature placed
safeguards within the statute to prevent citizens from bringing fraudulent â€œJohn Doeâ€ actions. Â The initial safeguard was a requirement that the unknown vehicle make â€œphysical contactâ€ with the plaintiffâ€™s car. Â Act No. 312, 1963 S.C. Acts 535.

    Then in 1987, the Legislature amended the statute once
    again to allow insureds to bring a â€œJohn Doeâ€ action regardless of
    physical contact as long as an independent person witnessed the accident.
     Act. No. 166, 1987 S.C. Acts 1122.
In 1989, the Legislature again amended the statute to require that the independent witness provide the court with a signed affidavit attesting to the unknown vehicleâ€™s involvement in the accident.

357 S.C. at 199-200, 592 S.E.2d at 627-28.Â  
The question for the Gilliland court was â€œto what extent an independent witness must testify about the causal connection between the unknown vehicle and the accident to satisfy the legislatureâ€™s intent to protect insurance companies from fraudulent claims in â€˜John Doeâ€™ actions.â€Â  Id. at 200, 592 S.E.2d at 628.Â  The court answered the question with the following analysis:

In Wausau Underwriters Ins. Co. v. Howser, 309 S.C. 269, 422 S.E.2d 106, (1992) this Court indicated that the statute required an independent witness to attest to facts that provide at least some causal connection between an unknown driver and the accident.Â  The Court provided that the adequacy of the â€œcausal connectionâ€ should pass the same test used in determining whether an injury or damage arose out of the ownership, maintenance, or use of the uninsured vehicle. Â Id. at 275, 422 S.E.2d at 110.Â  The Court explained that this test regarding the sufficiency of the evidence is â€œsomething less than proximate cause and something more than the vehicle being the mere site of the injury.â€Â  Id. at 272, 422 S.E.2d at 108 (citing Continental Western Ins. Co. v. Klug, 415 N.W.2d 876 (Minn. 1987)).
 Based on the test set forth in Howser, Â§ 38-77-170(2) may be satisfied even though an independent witness fails to provide a clear answer to
the question of proximate cause.Â  Howser suggests that Â§ 38-77-170(2) should be interpreted liberally.Â  This Court arguably abandoned a liberal interpretation of Â§ 38-77-170(2) in Collins v. Doe, 352 S.C. 462, 574 S.E.2d 739 (2002).
 In Collins, this Court strictly interpreted Â§ 38-77-170(2). Â This Court held that while the purpose of the affidavit requirement of Â§ 38-77-170(2) could have been met by witness testimony, the statute specifically required that the plaintiff provide an affidavit of an independent witness.
 Here, Â§ 38-77-170(2) provides that an independent witness must attest to â€œthe truth of the facts of the accident.â€ Â On one hand, Collins suggests that we should not apply standards that are not specifically set forth in the statute. Â On the other hand, the provision in question here is arguably ambiguous (while the affidavit requirement, according to Collins, is not); therefore, a strict interpretation of Â§ 38-77-170(2) would undermine the statuteâ€™s purpose. Â See Kiriakides v. United Artists Communications, Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994) (â€œHowever plain the ordinary meaning of the words used in a statute may be, [we] will reject that meaning when to accept it would lead to a result so plainly absurd that it could not possibly have intended by the Legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention.â€)

 In the case at hand, the Court of Appeals held that the witness must â€œbe able
to attest to the circumstances surrounding the accident, i.e., what actions of the unknown driver contributed to the accident.â€ Â Gilliland, 351 S.C. at 500, 570 S.E.2d at 548. Â We agree that this analysis is consistent with Howser and constitutes a fair interpretation of the ambiguous fact requirement of Â§ 38-77-170(2). Â However, the Court of Appeals found that Norris failed to attest to the existence of an unknown vehicle. Â Gilliland, 351 S.C. at 498, 570 S.E.2d at 546. Â We find the record includes sufficient evidence that an unknown vehicle was involved in Petitionerâ€™s accident.

Gilliland, 357 S.C. at 199-202, 592 S.E.2d at 628-29.Â  The linchpin of the courtâ€™s ruling was its determination that the witness affidavit contained circumstantial evidence corroborating Gillilandâ€™s testimony that an unknown vehicle contributed to her accident:

In Marks v. Indus. Life & Health Ins. Co., 212 S.C. 502, 505, 48 S.E.2d 445, 446, this Court held that â€œ[t]he attending circumstances along with direct testimony may be taken into account by the jury in arriving at its decision as any fact in issue may be established by circumstantial evidence, if the circumstances, which must themselves be proven lead to the conclusion with reasonable certainty.â€ 
 We now hold that the testimony of Gayle Norris contained circumstantial evidence that supports Petitionerâ€™s testimony that an unknown driver contributed to her accident. Â Norrisâ€™s testimony that she saw the lights of an unknown car that was turning around and fleeing the scene of the accident sufficiently corroborates Petitionerâ€™s testimony creating a question of fact as to causation for the jury.

Gilliland, 357 S.C. at 202, 592 S.E.2d at 629 (emphasis added).Â  
â€œFor circumstantial evidence to be sufficient to warrant the finding of a fact, the circumstances must lead to the conclusion with reasonable certainty and must have sufficient probative value to constitute the basis for a legal inference, not for mere speculation.â€Â  Gastineau v. Murphy, 331 S.C. 565, 570 n.2, 503 S.E.2d 712, 714 n.2 (1998) (citing Holland v. Georgia Hardwood Lumber Co., 214 S.C. 195, 204-05, 51 S.E.2d 744, 749 (1949)).Â  

Circumstantial evidence means proof that does not actually assert or represent the proposition in question, but that asserts or describes something else, from which the trier of fact may either (1) reasonably infer the truth of the proposition, in which case the evidence is not only relevant under Rule 401 but is sufficient as well, or (2) at least reasonably infer an increase in the probability that the proposition is in fact true, in which case the evidence is relevant under Rule 401 (assuming that the proposition is of consequence to the determination of the action) but may not be sufficient by itself to create a question for the trier of fact to decide.

29 Am. Jur. 2d Evidence Â§ 313 (1994) (emphasis added) (footnotes omitted).Â  
Unlike in Gilliland, the affidavits submitted by Shealy do not contain circumstantial evidence supporting the driverâ€™s version of the accident.Â  Shealy failed to corroborate the driverâ€™s account.Â  In Gilliland, the court found â€œthe testimony of Gail Norris contained circumstantial evidence that supports Petitionerâ€™s testimony.â€Â  357 S.C. at 202, 592 S.E.2d at 629 (emphasis added).Â  Contradistinctively, Shealyâ€™s affidavits merely repeat the driverâ€™s account and fail to provide any support for his assertions.Â Â  
The purpose of section 38-77-120(2) is to prevent fraud.Â  Concomitantly, the affidavit of the independent witness must contain some independent evidence that an unknown vehicle was involved in the accident.Â  Shealy failed to satisfy the statuteâ€™s mandate; thus, the court properly granted summary judgment.
II.Â  Admission Against Interest
Shealy contends the trial court erred in granting summary judgment to Doe because Safecoâ€™s letter constituted an admission against interest.Â  The trial court did not rule on this issue, and Shealy did not raise it in a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved.Â  See Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (finding where â€œthe circuit court did not explicitly ruleâ€ on an argument, and no Rule 59(e) motion was made, â€œthe issue was thus not properly before the Court of Appeals and should not have been addressedâ€); Jones v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 364 S.C. 222, 235, 612 S.E.2d 719, 726 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œAn issue is not preserved where the trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument and the appellant does not make a
Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment.â€); McCall v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 359 S.C. 372, 381, 597 S.E.2d 181, 186 (Ct. App. 2004) (holding an issue must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial court to be preserved for appellate review).Â  
Additionally, Shealy fails to cite any case law for this proposition and makes only conclusory arguments in support thereof.Â  Thus, Shealy has abandoned this issue on appeal.Â  See Mulherin-Howell v. Cobb, 362 S.C. 588, 600, 608 S.E.2d 587, 593-94 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting when an appellant fails to cite any supporting authority for his position and makes conclusory arguments, the appellant abandons the issue on appeal).Â  Accordingly, we decline to address this issue.
CONCLUSION
We hold Shealy failed to comply with the witness affidavit requirement of section 38-77-170(2).Â  Furthermore, Shealy failed to preserve the issue of whether Safecoâ€™s letter should be considered an admission against interest that precludes a grant of summary judgment.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order is 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

title: Stribling v. Stribling
description: Former wife appeals the family court's order directing her to sign a waiver of her beneficiary interest in her former Husband's retirement accounts.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Lyn Cherry Stribling as Personal Representative of Joseph Neal
Stribling, Respondent,
v.
Linda Diane Stribling, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
 Kellum W. Allen, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 4129
Heard April 6, 2006 â€“ Filed June 26, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Melissa J. Copeland, and Catherine H. Kennedy, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Robert K. Whitney, of Seneca, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.: Lyn Cherry Stribling (Widow), as personal representative of Joseph Neal Stribling (Husband), brought an action against Linda Dianne Stribling (Wife) seeking a court order requiring Wife to waive her claim to Husbandâ€™s Individual Retirement Accounts (IRAs) pursuant to a Divorce Decree.Â  Wife appeals the family courtâ€™s order, arguing the court erred in holding Wife waived interest in non-employment related retirement accounts and erred in holding any waiver applied to her expectancy interest.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
Husband and Wife married on December 22, 1973.Â  During their marriage, Husband established two IRAs: a Charles Schwab IRA in December of 1993 and a TD Waterhouse IRA in March of 1998.Â  Husband named Wife as primary beneficiary for both IRAs; a charity was also named as a five percent beneficiary for the Schwab IRA.Â  
In February 2003, Husband and Wife divorced pursuant to a Divorce Decree.Â  The Decree incorporated the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement.Â  The Decree and agreement awarded ownership of both IRAs to Husband.[1]Â  The Decree also provided, in relevant part:

The parties acknowledge that each party is retaining his or her retirement accounts accumulated through their respective employment.Â  The parties further acknowledge they are waiving any interest they may have in the other partyâ€™s retirement.Â  As a result, the parties agree to sign any and all documentation necessary to fully waive any right or entitlement he or she may have had in the retirement of the other.Â  The parties will fully cooperate in securing the necessary waivers, releases, QDROâ€™s or other required documents for the signature of the waiving party.Â  

Not long after the partiesâ€™ divorce, Husband married Widow.Â  Husband died on July 25, 2004.Â  At the time of Husbandâ€™s death, Wife was the named beneficiary of the Waterhouse IRA and the named beneficiary of ninety-five percent of the Schwab IRA.Â  On March 16, 2005, Widow, as personal representative of Husbandâ€™s estate, brought an action against Wife seeking a court order requiring Wife to waive her claim to Husbandâ€™s IRAs pursuant to the Divorce Decree. Â Â 
A hearing was held on May 3, 2005.Â  By order, the family court ruled that the â€œlanguage of the settlement is clear and sufficiently comprehensive so as to establish [Wife] had waived or relinquished any interest, including expectancy interest, in [Husbandâ€™s] retirement.â€Â  As a result, the court ordered Wife to sign documentation necessary to waive any rights or entitlement to the IRAs.Â  This appeal followed.Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to construe a written contract is an action at law.â€Â 
S. Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 349 S.C. 77, 80, 562 S.E.2d 482, 484 (Ct. App. 2002), affâ€™d as modified, 356 S.C. 444, 590 S.E.2d 27 (2003).Â  Whether a contractâ€™s language is ambiguous is a question of law. Â South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 623, 550 S.E.2d 299, 302-03 (2001).Â  â€œ[W]hen a contract is clear and unambiguous, the construction thereof is a question of law for the court.â€Â  Bowen v. Bowen, 345 S.C. 243, 249, 547 S.E.2d 877, 880 (Ct. App. 2001), affâ€™d, 352 S.C. 494, 575 S.E.2d 573 (2003).Â  â€œWhile a trial courtâ€™s findings of fact in a nonjury action at law should not be disturbed on appeal unless they are without evidentiary support, a reviewing court is free to decide questions of law with no particular deference to the trial court.â€Â  Hunt v. S.C. Forestry Commâ€™n, 358 S.C. 564, 569, 595 S.E.2d 849, 848-49 (Ct. App. 2004). Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.                 
Waiver of Interest in Husbandâ€™s IRAs 
Wife argues the family court erred in holding the Divorce Decree clearly established Wife waived her interest in the Husbandâ€™s IRAs.Â  Specifically, Wife asserts the Divorce Decree only establishes waiver of interest in employment related retirement accounts, and the Decree does not apply to the IRAs because they are non-employment retirement accounts.Â  We disagree. 
The construction of an agreement is a matter of contract law.Â  McDuffie v. McDuffie, 313 S.C. 397, 399, 438 S.E.2d 239, 241 (1993).Â  â€œIn construing a contract, the primary objective is to ascertain and give effect to the intention of the parties.â€Â 
S. Atl. Fin. Servs., 349 S.C. at 80, 562 S.E.2d at 484.Â  â€œThe partiesâ€™ intention must, in the first instance, be derived from the language of the contract.â€Â  Jacobs v. Serv. Merch. Co., 297 S.C. 123, 128, 375 S.E.2d 1, 4 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  â€œIf its language is plain, unambiguous, and capable of only one reasonable interpretation, no construction is required and the contractâ€™s language determines the instrumentâ€™s force and effect.â€Â  Id. Â â€œMere lack of clarity on casual reading is not the standard for determining whether a contract is afflicted with ambiguity.â€ Â Gamble, Givens & Moody v. Moise, 288 S.C. 210, 215, 341 S.E.2d 147, 150 (Ct. App. 1986).
We find the language of the Decree unambiguously provides Wife waived any interest in all of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts.Â  The relevant language of the Decree states that each of the parties retain their â€œretirement accounts accumulated through their respective employment.â€Â  The Decree then provides that the parties â€œfurther acknowledge they are waiving any interest they may have in the other partyâ€™s retirement.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The inclusion of the word â€œfurtherâ€ indicates that, in addition to each party retaining their respective employment-related retirement accounts, each party waives any interest in any of the other partyâ€™s retirement.Â  The Decree does not limit this waiver of interest to employment related retirement accounts, but rather simply states the waiver applies to the â€œother partyâ€™s retirement.â€Â  This interpretation is further substantiated by the settlement agreement which specifically lists both IRAs in Husbandâ€™s column.Â  Accordingly, after looking at the Decree as a whole, we find the trial court did not err in finding the Decree was clearly and sufficiently comprehensive to establish Wife waived any interest in Husbandâ€™s retirement, including Husbandâ€™s IRAs.Â  
II.              
Expectancy Interest 
Wife next contends the family court erred in finding any waiver of interest in Husbandâ€™s IRAs encompassed a waiver of an expectancy interest in the IRAs.Â  We disagree. 
Generally, in South Carolina, divorce does not per se affect the rights of a beneficiary interest.Â  See, e.g., Duncan v. Investors Diversified Serv., Inc., 285 S.C. 467, 470, 330 S.E.2d 295, 296 (1985) (holding divorce does not of itself operate to defeat the beneficiaryâ€™s claim to proceeds under a life insurance policy). Â However, it is generally recognized that a beneficiary may contract away the beneficiary interest through a separation or property settlement agreement, even if the beneficiary designation is not formally changed.Â  Estate of Revis by Revis v. Revis, 326 S.C. 470, 477, 484 S.E.2d 112, 116 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  

In Estate of Revis, this court held: 
  
[W]hen a separation agreement does not specifically address a life insurance policy in which one spouse has an expectancy as a named beneficiary, general language of release . . . is not controlling on the issue. Where the insured spouse maintains ownership and control of the policy, including the right to change
beneficiaries, the question of whether or not the agreement extinguishes the right of the named beneficiary to claim the benefits upon the death of the estranged spouse depends upon the intention of the insured spouse as determined by the facts of each case.
  

Id. at 478, 484 S.E.2d at 116-17.Â  The beneficiary interest in a life insurance policy is analogous to the beneficiary interest in an IRA.Â  Like the beneficiary in a life insurance policy, the IRA beneficiary merely has an expectancy interest in the IRA until the ownerâ€™s death.Â  See Luszcz v. Lavoie, 787 So. 2d 245, 248 (Fla. 2d Dist. Ct. App. 2001) (in holding that the IRA beneficiary designation controlled in a case where the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement did not include releases of claims against each other, the court noted that â€œa beneficiaryâ€™s rights to proceeds do not attach until the IRA ownerâ€™s death.Â  Until then, the beneficiary merely has an expectancy in the IRA because until the ownerâ€™s death, the owner can do with the IRA as desired, including changing the beneficiary designation or cashing out the account altogetherâ€); Rishel v. Estate of Rishel, 781 N.E.2d 735, 742 (Ind. Ct. App. 2003) (in finding that the partiesâ€™ settlement agreement only included a waiver of property in general and did not amount to a specific waiver of an expectancy interest in an annuity, the court noted there was no distinction between the expectancy interest in life insurance policies, retirement accounts, and annuities).Â  Â Â 
In Rushton v. Lott, this court, quoting the above language in Estate of Revis, held a separation agreement may be interpreted to preclude a beneficiaryâ€™s interest in an annuity even though the agreement did not specifically mention the annuity.Â  Rushton v. Lott, 330 S.C. 418, 420, 499 S.E.2d 222, 224 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The separation agreement in Rushton provided: â€œEach party shall retain exclusive ownership and possession of their respective savings, checking or retirement accounts now in their possession.â€Â  Id. at 420, 499 S.E.2d at 223.Â  The court held the agreement precluded the named beneficiary from claiming rights to the proceeds of an annuity because parol evidence indicated the parties viewed the annuity as an IRA and, therefore, intended to include the annuity in the separation agreement.Â  In Rushton, this court upheld the trial courtâ€™s use of parol evidence to determine the separation agreement applied to an annuity.Â  Id. at 421, 499 S.E.2d at 224.Â  Â Â 
Thus, in South Carolina, a separation agreement may preclude a named beneficiary from recovery of an expectancy interest in two ways.Â  First, a named beneficiary may be precluded from recovery when a separation agreement specifically addresses a particular policy/account providing an expectancy interest and the agreement contains language of release applicable to the policy/account.Â  Second, when a separation agreement provides general language of release without specifically addressing the policy/account providing the expectancy interest, a named beneficiary may be precluded from recovery when the policy/account owner intended for the general waiver to apply to the expectancy interest.Â  In other words, for separation agreements that do not specifically address a policy/account providing an expectancy interest, a general waiver is not controlling, and the effect of the general release on the expectancy interest â€œdepends upon the intention of the [policy/account owning] spouse as determined by the facts of each case.â€Â Â  Estate of Revis, 326 S.C. at 478, 484 S.E.2d at 117. 
In this case, we find the waiver contained in the separation agreement is controlling because the agreement specifically addresses the IRAs.Â  The agreement provides the parties waive â€œany interest they may have in the other partyâ€™s retirement.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The agreement then clearly lists the IRAs in Husbandâ€™s column and provides â€œHusband will receive all assets in his column.â€ Â Thus, the agreement specifically references the IRAs providing the expectancy interest and is accompanied by a clear waiver of any interest, including present or future interests.Â  Accordingly, we find the family court did not err in finding Wife waived her expectancy interest in Husbandâ€™s IRAs. 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the family court did not err in finding Wife waived her interest in Husbandâ€™s IRAs.Â  The decision of the court is accordingly
 AFFIRMED.
 SHORT, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] The Decree provided that â€œ[t]he parties have agreed to a division of their assets as set out in [their settlement agreement]â€ and â€œWife will receive all assets in her column, and Husband will receive all assets in his column.â€Â  The settlement agreement listed both IRA accounts in Husbandâ€™s column.Â Â Â
